{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} [[File:Soccer goalkeeper.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A goalkeeper in action.]] The '''goalkeeper''', often shortened to '''keeper''' or '''goalie''', is one of the major [[association football positions|positions]] of [[association football]]. It is the most specialised position in the sport. The goalkeeper's primary role is to prevent the opposing [[football team|team]] from [[Scoring in association football|scoring]] (moving the [[football (ball)|ball]] over the defended [[Association football pitch#Goals|goal-line]] within the frame of the [[Football_pitch#Goals|goal]]). This is accomplished by the goalkeeper moving into the path of the ball and either catching it or directing it away from the vicinity of the goal line. Within the [[penalty area]] goalkeepers are able to use their hands, making them (outside [[throw-ins]]) the only players on the field permitted to handle the ball. The special status of goalkeepers is indicated by them wearing different coloured [[Kit (association football)|kits]] from their teammates.
The [[back pass rule]] prevents goalkeepers handling direct passes back to them from teammates. Goalkeepers usually perform [[goal kicks]], and also give commands to their defense during [[corner kicks]], [[direct free kick|direct]] and [[indirect free kicks]], and [[marking (association football)|marking]]. Goalkeepers play an important role in directing on field [[Association football tactics and skills|strategy]] as they have an unrestricted view of the entire [[Pitch (sports field)|pitch]], giving them a unique perspective on play development.
The goalkeeper is the only required position of a team. If they are [[sport injury|injured]] or [[Red card (association football)|sent off]], a substitute goalkeeper has to take their place, otherwise an outfield player must take the ejected keeper's place in goal. In order to replace a goalkeeper who is sent off, a team usually substitutes an outfield player for the backup keeper (thus effectively the red card and substitution takes out two of the starting eleven players). They then play the remainder of the match with nine outfield players. If a team does not have a substitute goalkeeper, or they have already used all of their permitted substitutions for the match, an outfield player has to take the dismissed goalkeeper's place and wear the goalkeeper shirt.
The [[squad number (association football)|squad number]] for a first choice goalkeeper is generally number 1.<ref name="sports.yahoo.com">{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/soccer-dirty-tackle/mystery-solved--why-do-the-best-soccer-players-wear-no--10-052229677.html|title=Mystery solved: Why do the best soccer players wear No. 10?|publisher=Yahoo|author1=Khalil Garriot|date=21 June 2014|accessdate=19 May 2015}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Footb incident painting.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A goalkeeper being charged by a rival player (1905).]] Association football, like many sports, has experienced many changes in tactics resulting in the generation and elimination of different positions. Goalkeeper is the only position that is certain to have existed since the codification of the sport. Even in the early days of organised football, when systems were limited or non-existent and the main idea was for all players to attack and defend, teams had a designated member to play as the goalkeeper.
The earliest account of football teams with player positions comes from [[Richard Mulcaster]] in 1581 and does not specify goalkeepers. The earliest specific reference to keeping goal comes from [[Cornish Hurling]] in 1602. According to Carew: "they pitch two bushes in the ground, some eight or ten foot asunder; and directly against them, ten or twelve score off, other twayne in like distance, which they term their Goals. One of these is appointed by lots, to the one side, and the other to his adverse party. There is assigned for their guard, a couple of their best stopping Hurlers".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext06/srvcr10.txt |title=The Survey of Cornwall by Richard Carew |date= |accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> Other references to scoring goals begin in English literature in the early 16th century; for example, in [[John Day (dramatist)|John Day]]'s play ''The Blind Beggar of [[Bethnal Green]]'' (performed circa 1600; published 1659): "I'll play a gole at [[camping (game)|camp-ball]]" (an extremely violent variety of football, popular in [[East Anglia]]). Similarly, in a 1613 poem, [[Michael Drayton]] refers to "when the Ball to throw, And drive it to the Gole, in squadrons forth they goe". It seems inevitable that wherever a game has evolved goals, some form of goalkeeping must also be developed. [[David Wedderburn (writer)|David Wedderburn]] refers to what has been translated from [[Latin]] as to "keep goal" in 1633, though this does not necessarily imply a fixed goalkeeper position.
The word "goal-keeper" is used in the novel ''[[Tom Brown's School Days]]'' (published in 1857, but set in the 1830s). The author is here referring to an early form of [[rugby football]]: {{quote|You will see in the first place, that the sixth-form boy, who has the charge of goal, has spread his force (the goal-keepers) so as to occupy the whole space behind the goal-posts, at distances of about five yards apart; a safe and well-kept goal is the foundation of all good play.<ref>{{cite book |page=112 |url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/hvd.hwkq5n?urlappend=%3Bseq=126 |title=School Days at Rugby |author=An Old Boy [Thomas Hughes] |year=1857 |location=Boston |publisher=Ticknor and Fields}}</ref>}}
The word "goal-keeper" appeared in the [[Sheffield Rules]] of 1867, but the term did not refer to a designated player, but rather to "that player on the defending side who for the time being is nearest to his own goal". The goal-keeper, thus defined, did not enjoy any special handling privileges.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Sheffield Football Association | authorlink=Sheffield Football Association | year=1867 | title=Sheffield Rules (March 1867) }}</ref>
The FA's first Laws of the Game of 1863 did not make any special provision for a goalkeeper, with any player being allowed to catch or knock-on the ball.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Football Association | authorlink=Football Association | year=1863 | title=Laws of the Game (1863) }}</ref> Handling the ball was completely forbidden (for all players) in 1870.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Football Association | authorlink=Football Association | year=1870 | title=Laws of the Game (1870) }}</ref> The next year, 1871, the laws were amended to introduce the goalkeeper and specify that the keeper was allowed to handle the ball "for the protection of his goal".<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Football Association | authorlink=Football Association | year=1871 | title=Laws of the Game (1871) }}</ref> The restrictions on the ability of the goalkeeper to handle the ball were changed several times in subsequent revisions of the laws:
* 1871: the keeper may handle the ball only "for the protection of his goal". * 1873: the keeper may not "carry" the ball.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Football Association | authorlink=Football Association | year=1873 | title=Laws of the Game (1873) }}</ref> * 1883: the keeper may not carry the ball for more than two steps.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=Football Association | authorlink=Football Association | year=1883 | title=Laws of the Game (1883) }}</ref> * 1887: the keeper may not handle the ball in the opposition's half.<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=International Football Association Board | authorlink= International Football Association Board | year=1887 | title=Laws of the Game (1887) }}</ref> * 1901: the keeper may handle the ball for any purpose (not only in defence of the goal).<ref>{{cite wikisource | author=International Football Association Board| authorlink=International Football Association Board | year=1901 | title=Laws of the Game (1901) }}</ref> * 1912: the keeper may handle the ball only in the penalty area. * 1931: the keeper may take up to four steps (rather than two) while carrying the ball.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Football |page=3 |work=Carluke & Lanark Gazette |date=19 July 1931}}</ref> * 1992: the keeper may not handle the ball after it has been deliberately kicked to him/her by a team-mate. * 1997: the keeper may not handle the ball for more than six seconds.
Initially, goalkeepers typically played between the goalposts and had limited mobility, except when trying to save opposition shots. Throughout the years, the role of the goalkeeper has evolved, due to the changes in systems of play, to become more active. The goalkeeper is the only player in association football allowed to use their hands to control the ball (other than during throw-ins).
Due to several time-wasting techniques which were used by goalkeepers, such as bouncing the ball on the ground or throwing it in the air and then catching it again, in the 1960s, the Laws of the game were revised further, and the goalkeeper was given a maximum of four steps to travel while holding, bouncing or throwing the ball in the air and catching it again, without having to release it into play. The FIFA Board later also devised an anti-parrying rule, saying that such deliberate parrying for the purpose of evading the Law was to be regarded also as holding the ball.<ref name="Goalkeepers are not above the Law">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/news/y=1997/m=10/news=goalkeepers-are-not-above-the-law-72050.html|title=Goalkeepers are not above the Law|publisher=FIFA.com|date=31 October 1997|accessdate=19 July 2017}}</ref>
In 1992, the [[International Football Association Board]] made changes in the laws of the game that affected goalkeepers – notably the [[back-pass rule]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/history/law/summary.html |title=From 1863 to the Present Day |publisher=FIFA.com |date= |accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> which prohibits goalkeepers from handling the ball when receiving a deliberate pass from a teammate that is made with their feet. This rule change was made to discourage time-wasting and overly defensive play after the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] which was described as exceedingly dull, rife with back-passing and goalkeepers holding the ball. Also, goalkeepers would frequently drop the ball and dribble it around, only to pick it up again once opponents came closer to put them under pressure, a typical time-wasting technique. Therefore, another rule was introduced at the same time as the back-pass rule. This rule prohibits the goalkeeper from handling the ball again once he or she has released it for play; an offence results in an indirect free kick to the opposition. Furthermore any player negating the spirit of the new rule would be likely to be cautioned for unsporting behaviour and punished by an indirect free-kick.<ref name="Goalkeepers are not above the Law"/>
On 1 July 1997, FIFA decided to extend the back-pass rule by applying it also to throw-ins from [[Defender (association football)|defenders]] to their own goalkeeper; in order to prevent further time-wasting, FIFA also established that if a goalkeeper holds the ball for more than five or six seconds the referee must adjudge this as time-wasting and award an indirect free-kick to the opposing team.<ref name="Goalkeepers are not above the Law"/>
==Laws of the Game and general play == [[File:Suarez Ajax captain.jpg|thumb|right|222px|[[Maksym Koval]] closes down [[Luis Suárez]].]] The position of goalkeeper is the only position in the game which is technically distinct from the others in the course of normal play. The [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]] distinguish the goalkeeper from the other players in several ways, most significantly exempting them from the prohibition on handling the ball, though only within their own penalty area.<ref name="laws" /> Once a goalkeeper has control of the ball in their hands, opponents are not permitted to challenge them.<ref name="laws" /> Goalkeepers have a specialised role as the sole defender in [[penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]]s and [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-outs]].<ref name="laws" /> Goalkeepers are required to wear distinct colours from other players, and are permitted to wear caps and tracksuit bottoms.<ref name="laws">{{cite web|title=Laws|url=http://www.theifab.com/laws|website=International Football Association Board {{!}} IFAB|publisher=[[International Football Association Board]]|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref>
The Laws mandate that one player on the team must be designated as the goalkeeper at all times, meaning that if a goalkeeper is [[Fouls_and_misconduct_(association_football)#Red_card_(removal)|sent off]] or injured and unable to continue another player must assume the goalkeeper position.<ref name="laws" /> The Laws allow for teams to change the player designated as goalkeeper at stoppages in play,<ref name="laws" /> but in practice this is rarely exercised.
The Laws place no restrictions on a goalkeeper leaving their penalty area and acting as an ordinary player, though generally goalkeepers stay close to their goal throughout the match.
Goalkeepers routinely perform extension dives. To execute this, they push off the ground with the foot nearest to the ball, launching themselves into a horizontal position. At this point, the ball may be caught or parried away from the goal. In the latter case, a good goalkeeper will attempt to ensure that the rebound cannot be taken by a player of the opposing team, although this is not always possible.
==Responsibilities== [[File:U20-WorldCup2007-Okotie-Onka edit2.jpg|thumb|A goalkeeper making a save]] The tactical responsibilities of goalkeepers include:
* To '''keep goal''' by physically blocking attempted shots with any part of their body. The keeper is permitted to ''play'' the ball anywhere on the field, but may not ''handle'' the ball using hands or outstretched arms outside his/her penalty area. * To organise the team's defenders during defensive set pieces such as free kicks and corners. In the case of free kicks, this includes picking the numbers and the organisation of a defensive man "wall". The wall serves to provide a physical barrier to the incoming ball, but some goalkeepers position their wall in a certain position to tempt the kick-taker to a certain type of shot. Occasionally, goalkeepers may opt to dispense with the wall. Some goalkeepers are also entrusted with the responsibility of picking markers while defending at set pieces. * To '''pick out crosses and attempted long passes''' either by collecting them in flight or punching them clear if heavily challenged by opposing strikers.
Although goalkeepers have special privileges, including the ability to handle the ball in the penalty area, they are otherwise subject to the same rules as any other player.
===Goalkeepers in playmaking and attack=== [[File:Mathew Ryan Club Brugge.jpg|right|thumb|Australian goalkeeper [[Mathew Ryan]]<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ryan |first=Mathew |title=Mathew Ryan is a young, Australian keeper with good reflexes and a very good set of feet. |date=12 June 2013 |url=http://clubbrugge.be/en/players/first-team/players/mathew-ryan |accessdate=12 June 2013 |publisher=clubbrugge.be |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707113807/http://clubbrugge.be/en/players/first-team/players/mathew-ryan |archivedate=7 July 2015 }}</ref> playing with his feet.]] Goalkeepers are not required to stay in the penalty area; they may get involved in play anywhere on the pitch, and it is common for them to act as an [[Defender (association football)#Sweeper (libero)|additional defender (or 'sweeper')]] during certain passages of the game. Goalkeepers with a long throwing range or accurate long-distance kicks may be able to quickly [[Playmaker#Playmaking in other positions|create]] attacking positions for a team and generate goal-scoring chances from defensive situations, a tactic known as the [[long ball]].
====Sweeper-keeper==== {{seealso|Rush goalie}} [[Gyula Grosics]] from the [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] "[[Golden Team]]" of the 1950s was thought to be the first goalkeeper to play as the 'sweeper-keeper'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1781995-the-50-greatest-goalkeepers-in-history/page/24|title=The 50 Greatest Goalkeepers in History|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=27 September 2013|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> [[Tommy Lawrence]] has also been credited with revolutionising the role of the goalkeeper by effectively acting as a 11th outfield player.<ref name="losing">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/fabien-barthez-the-goalkeepers-fear-of-losing-it-9271816.html|title=Fabien Barthez: The goalkeeper's fear of losing it|publisher=The Independent|author1=James Lawton|date=27 November 2001|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> The rushing playing style used by Liverpool legend [[Bruce Grobbelaar]] seen during the 1980s–90s makes him one of the original sweeper-keepers of the modern era.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thinkfootball.co.uk/was-bruce-grobbelaar-the-original-sweeper-keeper/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=12 September 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150508100526/http://thinkfootball.co.uk/was-bruce-grobbelaar-the-original-sweeper-keeper/ |archivedate=8 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[René Higuita]] was another who became known for his unorthodox, skilful but sometimes reckless techniques.<ref>Tim Vickery (10 February 2010). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/legacy/timvickery/2010/02/the_legacy_of_rene_higuita.html "The Legacy of Rene Higuita"]. BBC. Retrieved 11 June 2014</ref> As of 2011, [[Manuel Neuer]] has been described as a sweeper-keeper due to his speed and unique style of play which occasionally includes him acting as a sweeper for his team by rushing off his line to anticipate opposing [[Forward (association football)|forwards]] who have beaten the [[offside trap]].<ref name=evolution>{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/manuel-neuer-and-evolution-goalkeeper|title=Manuel Neuer and the evolution of the goalkeeper|publisher=FourFourTwo|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=thescore>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/news/646883|title=Why Manuel Neuer should not win the Ballon d'Or|publisher=The Score|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> With his excellent ball control and distribution, which enables him to start plays from the back,<ref name=evolution/><ref name=thescore/> he has said he could play in the [[3. Liga|German third division]] as a centre-back if he wanted to.<ref name="The Score">{{cite web | url = http://www.the42.ie/manuel-neuer-world-cup-2014-1564873-Jul2014/ | title = Why Manuel Neuer was the best player at the 2014 World Cup | publisher = The42 | date = 14 July 2014 | accessdate = 16 July 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/these-football-times/2014/jul/16/manuel-neuer-germany-revolutionising-goalkeeping-world-cup-bayern-munich | title = How Manuel Neuer, Germany's 11th man, is revolutionising goalkeeping | work = The Guardian | first = Paddy | last = Vipond | date = 16 July 2014 | accessdate = 16 July 2014 }}</ref> [[Hugo Lloris]] of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and [[France national football team|France]], and former goalkeepers [[Fabien Barthez]] and [[Edwin van der Sar]], have also been described as sweeper-keepers,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Jonathan|title=Tottenham's Hugo Lloris is Premier League's supreme sweeper-keeper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/feb/13/tottenham-hugo-lloris-premier-league-sweeper-keeper|accessdate=11 May 2017|work=The Guardian|date=13 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester-united-david-de-gea-8946453|title=Manchester United: David de Gea has made goalkeeping cool|publisher=Manchester Evening News|author1=Samuel Luckhurst|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=13 January 2018}}</ref> while [[Claudio Bravo]] of Manchester City has even been described as a [[Playmaker#Playmaking in other positions|''playmaker'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37610692|title='Man City's Claudio Bravo is a playmaker not sweeper-keeper'|publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>
====Goalscorers==== [[File:Rogério Ceni.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Rogério Ceni]] is the highest-scoring goalkeeper of all time, with over 100 career goals.]] Some [[List of goalscoring goalkeepers|goalkeepers have scored goals]]. Other than by accident when a long kicked clearance reaches the other end of the field and evades the opposing goalkeeper with the aid of strong winds and/or unexpected bounces, this most commonly occurs where a goalkeeper has rushed up to the opposite end of the pitch to give his team a numerical advantage in attack, leaving his own goal undefended. As such, it is normally only done late in a game at [[Set piece (football)|set-piece]]s where the consequences of scoring far outweigh those of conceding a further goal, such as for a team trailing in a knock-out tournament.
Some goalkeepers, such as Higuita, [[Rogério Ceni]], [[Hans-Jörg Butt]] and [[José Luis Chilavert]], are also expert set-piece takers. These players may take their team's attacking [[Direct free kick|free kicks]] or [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalties]]. Ceni, [[São Paulo FC|São Paulo]]'s long-time custodian, has scored 100 goals in his career, more than many outfield players.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33006305|title=Rogerio Ceni: Sao Paulo keeper into club record books|publisher=BBC|date=4 June 2015|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://www.fifa.com/newscentre/features/news/newsid=1306860/index.html "They said it: Jose Luis Chilavert"]. ''FIFA.com''. 24 September 2010. Retrieved 13 March 2013.</ref>
==Equipment and attire== [[File:Liverpool FC team v FC Gomel.jpg|thumb|333px|[[Liverpool F.C.]] team photo prior to their [[UEFA Europa League]] clash against [[FC Gomel]]. Note the differing attire of goalkeeper [[Brad Jones (footballer)|Brad Jones]] with that of the rest of his teammates.]] Goalkeepers must wear [[kit (association football)|kit]] that distinguishes them clearly from other players and match officials, as this is all that the FIFA [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]] require. Some goalkeepers have received recognition for their match attire, like [[Lev Yashin]] of the [[Soviet Union national football team|Soviet Union]], who was nicknamed the "Black Spider" for his distinctive all-black outfit;<ref name="FIFA">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/players/player=174638/|title="Yashin, the impregnable Spider".}} FIFA. Retrieved 23 November 2013</ref><ref name="ESPN">Lomas, Mark (29 April 2010) {{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/print?id=779000&type=story |title="Lev Yashin: Russian Revolutionary". |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140522194557/http://www.espnfc.com/print?id=779000&type=story |archivedate=22 May 2014 |df= }} ESPN. Retrieved 21 May 2014</ref> [[Klaus Lindenberger]] of [[Austria national football team|Austria]], who designed his own variation of a [[clown]]'s costume; [[Jorge Campos]] of [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], who was popular for his colourful attire;<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0335hxv |title=Mexico's Jorge Campos: 'I'm not crazy!' |publisher=BBC World Service |date=22 September 2015 |accessdate=28 June 2018 }}</ref> [[Raul Plassman]] of [[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube]] and his all-yellow outfit; and [[Gábor Király]] for wearing a pair of grey [[Sweatpants|tracksuit bottoms]] instead of shorts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/1LhR2yyxwJDLS8KjysBnkPk/euro-2016-gabor-kiraly-hungarys-record-breaker-his-tracksuit-bottoms|title=Sportsworld – Euro 2016: Gabor Kiraly – Hungary's record breaker & his tracksuit bottoms?|publisher=BBC World Service}}</ref>
Although it was initially more common for goalkeepers to wear long-sleeved jerseys, recently several goalkeepers, such as [[Gianluigi Buffon]], have also been known to wear short-sleeves.<ref name=2002WC>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/team_pages/italy/squad/newsid_1858000/1858449.stm|title=Gianluigi Buffon|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 April 2002|accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="Gianluigi Buffon, One-on-One">{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/gianluigi-buffon-one-one-you-have-be-a-real-masochist-play-goal-and-a-bit-perverse?page=0%2C2|title=Gianluigi Buffon, One-on-One: You have to be a real masochist to play in goal – and a bit perverse|publisher=FourFourTwo|author1=Matt Barker|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/premium/plus/Calcio/Squadre/Juventus/04-05-2012/zoff-sereno-buffon-resti-grande-911128874332.shtml|title=Zoff: "Sereno Buffon Resti un grande"|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|author1=Gaetano Imparato|date=5 May 2012|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/news/706288|title=Still among football's elite, Juventus icon Buffon will be vital vs. Dortmund|publisher=The Score|author1=Paolo Bandini|date=24 February 2015|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref>
Most goalkeepers also wear [[Goalkeeper gloves|gloves]] to improve their grip on the ball, and to protect themselves from injury. Some gloves now include rigid plastic spines down each finger to help prevent injuries such as jammed, fractured, and [[sprain]]ed fingers. Though gloves are not mandatory attire, it is uncommon for goalkeepers to opt against them due to the advantages they offer. At [[UEFA Euro 2004]], [[Portugal national football team|Portuguese]] goalkeeper [[Ricardo (footballer, born 1976)|Ricardo]] famously took off his gloves during the quarter-final penalty shoot-out against [[England national football team|England]], knowing he was the next taker for his side. He then went on to save [[Darius Vassell]]'s penalty using his bare hands before scoring his own kick to win it for Portugal.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3830451.stm Portugal break England hearts]; BBC Sport, 24 June 2004</ref>
After recovering from a serious head injury that he had sustained in 2006, [[Petr Čech]] has subsequently worn a [[scrum cap|rugby style headguard]] during his matches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6258681.stm |title=Liverpool 2–0 Chelsea |work=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date= 20 January 2007|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref><ref name=sponsor2008>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/3701996/Petr-Cech-follows-Zinedine-Zidane-in-sponsorship-deal-Football.html |title=Petr Cech follows Zinedine Zidane in sponsorship deal |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=13 March 2012 |work=The Daily Telegraph |last=Benammar |first=Emily }}</ref>
==Careers and injuries== Goalkeepers often have longer playing careers than outfield players, many not retiring until their late thirties or early forties. This can be explained by noting that goalkeepers play a less physically demanding position that requires significantly less running. For example, Peter Shilton played for 31 years between 1966 and 1997 before retiring at the age of 47. Another explanation of this is that due to the nature of this position, goalkeepers use their experience more often than field players.
Lower and upper extremity injuries are very common and vary from [[Articular cartilage injuries|cartilage tears]], [[Anterior cruciate ligament injury|anterior cruciate ligaments (ACL)]], and [[Sprain#Joints involved|knee sprains]]. In general, goalkeepers can incur any injury that their outfield counterparts are also vulnerable to. The main exception to this guideline is that goalkeepers, as they run much less than outfield players, very rarely fall victim to fatigue-related injuries, such as [[Exercise-associated muscle cramps|leg cramps]], [[pulled hamstring]]s, and [[dehydration]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burger|first1=Rob|last2=Fine|first2=Kenneth|title=Soccer Injuries|url=http://www.stopsportsinjuries.org/soccer-injury-prevention.aspx#common|website=Stop Sports Injuries|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
==Records== [[File:Oliver Kahn 06-2004.jpg|thumb|right|[[Oliver Kahn]], the only goalkeeper to win the [[FIFA World Cup awards#Golden Ball|FIFA World Cup Golden Ball]] award.]] [[File:LevYashin.JPG|thumb|right|[[Lev Yashin]], the only goalkeeper to win the [[Ballon d'Or (1956–2009)|Ballon d'Or]].]] [[File:Kepa Arrizabalaga (6).jpg|thumb|right|[[Kepa Arrizabalaga|Kepa]] is the world's most expensive goalkeeper, moving from [[Athletic Bilbao|Athletic]] to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for €80 million.]] [[File:DK-Porto15 (9).jpg|thumb|right|[[Iker Casillas]] holds numerous goalkeeping records, and was the first goalkeeper ever, both male and female, to keep 100 international clean sheets.]] [[File:Hope in San Jose.jpg|thumb|right|[[Hope Solo]] holds the record for most international clean sheets by any goalkeeper, along with Iker Casillas.]] Goalkeepers are crucial in penalty shoot-outs. The record for most penalties saved in a shoot-out is held by [[Helmuth Duckadam]] of [[FC Steaua București|Steaua București]]. Duckadam defended four consecutive penalties in the [[1986 European Cup Final]] against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.worldrecordacademy.com/games/First_goalkeeper_who_saved_four_consecutive_penalties_Helmuth_Duckadam_set_world_record_112237.html|work=worldrecordacedemy.com | title=First goalkeeper who saved four consecutive penalties: Helmuth Duckadam set world record (Video) |date= 7 May 2011| accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> [[Stefano Tacconi]] is the only goalkeeper to have won all official club competitions (that he was eligible for).<ref>{{cite web|title=Journey through the Stars: Stefano Tacconi|url=http://www.juventus.com/juve/en/news/eng_aus%20tacconi%2023giugno2011%20news|publisher=Juventus.com|accessdate=1 June 2015|date=24 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141224020700/http://www.juventus.com/juve/en/news/eng_aus%20tacconi%2023giugno2011%20news|archivedate=24 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[José Luis Chilavert]] is the only goalkeeper to score a [[hat-trick]] (three goals in a game), doing so through [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]]s. He also was a [[Direct free kick|free kick]] expert. [[Rogério Ceni]] has scored the most goals for a goalkeeper, having scored his 100th goal in official games on 27 March 2011. Ceni scored his goals through free kicks and penalty kicks.<ref>[http://www.iffhs.de/?b4a390f03be4ac07cda15b45fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aee1a The World's most successful goalscoring Goalkeepers of all time], ''[[IFFHS]]'', 23 October 2006.</ref>
Gianluigi Buffon is currently the only goalkeeper to have won the [[UEFA Club Footballer of the Year|UEFA Club Footballer of the Year Award]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Buffon hailed after 500th Juventus appearance|url=http://m.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/2174295/|accessdate=9 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210004127/http://m.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/2174295/|archivedate=10 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Oliver Kahn holds the record for most UEFA Best Club Goalkeeper and [[Best European Goalkeeper]] Awards, with four.<ref>{{cite web|title=UEFA Club Goalkeeper of the Year|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1498484.html|website=uefa.com|accessdate=11 February 2015}}</ref> [[Iker Casillas]] holds the record for most appearances by a goalkeeper in the [[FIFPro World XI]], and in the [[UEFA Team of the Year]]; he also holds the record for the most [[IFFHS World's Best Goalkeeper]] Awards, alongside Buffon,<ref name="BUFFON MAKES IT FIVE">{{cite web|url=http://iffhs.de/the-worlds-best-goalkeeper-2017-gianluigi-buffon-makes-it-five/|title=THE WORLD’S BEST GOALKEEPER 2017: GIANLUIGI BUFFON MAKES IT FIVE!|publisher=IFFHS.de|date=3 December 2017|accessdate=3 December 2017}}</ref> winning the Award for five consecutive years between 2008–2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iker Casillas named World's Best Goalkeeper by IFFHS|url=http://sports.terra.com/soccer/iker-casillas-named-worlds-best-goalkeeper-by-iffhs,2c8f27e84a60c310VgnVCM4000009bcceb0aRCRD.html|accessdate=11 February 2015}}</ref> Casillas also holds the record for the most clean-sheets in UEFA Champions League history.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Edward Bennett|title=Most clean sheets in Champions League history: Iker Casillas moves ahead of Chelsea & Man United legends|url=http://www.caughtoffside.com/2015/04/23/most-clean-sheets-in-champions-league-history-iker-casillas-moves-ahead-of-chelsea-man-united-legends/7/|accessdate=1 June 2015|date=23 April 2015}}</ref>
At international level, [[Dino Zoff]] is the goalkeeper who has remained unbeaten for the longest period of time,<ref>{{cite web|title=Dino Zoff|url=http://www.planetworldcup.com/LEGENDS/zoff.html|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> whilst [[Walter Zenga]] holds the [[FIFA World Cup records#Goalkeeping|record]] for the longest unbeaten run in a [[FIFA World Cup]] tournament, as he went unbeaten for 517 minutes in the 1990 edition of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zenga: I've Dedicated My Life to Football|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1455638.html|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> Gianluigi Buffon, [[Fabien Barthez]] and Iker Casillas hold the [[FIFA World Cup records#Goalkeeping|record]] for fewest goals conceded by a winning goalkeeper in a World Cup tournament, only conceding two goals and leading their team to victory, as they were also awarded the [[Yashin Award]] for best keeper. Gianluigi Buffon is also the only World Cup winning goalkeeper not to have conceded a goal in open play throughout the whole tournament (one goal coming from an own goal after a free-kick, and the second from a penalty). Fabien Barthez and [[Peter Shilton]] hold the [[FIFA World Cup records#Goalkeeping|record]] for most [[Shutout#Association football|clean sheet]]s in World Cup matches, with 10 clean sheets each. [[Mohamed Al-Deayea]] holds the record for [[List of footballers with 100 or more caps|most international caps by a goalkeeper, with 178 official appearances]] for [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/15730285 |title=Egypt's Ahmed Hassan equals international apperance [sic] record |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2017 }}</ref>
[[Pascal Zuberbühler]] holds the [[FIFA World Cup records#Goalkeeping|record]] for fewest goals conceded by a goalkeeper in a World Cup tournament and holds the record for most successive matches at an international tournament without conceding (five games), he did not concede a goal in 463 minutes of World Cup games against hard shots from France, South Korea, and Togo as his team lost in the last 16 on penalties against Ukraine. Zuberbühler made Switzerland the only team in the history of the tournament not to concede a goal in normal time. [[Tim Howard]] holds the record for most saves made in a [[FIFA World Cup]] match, with 16 saves against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in the Round of 16 of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. [[Oliver Kahn]] is the only goalkeeper to have won the [[Adidas Golden Ball]] for the best player of the tournament in a World Cup (in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 competition]]); [[Lev Yashin]] is the only goalkeeper to have won the [[Ballon d'Or]]. [[Gianluca Pagliuca]] of [[Italy national football team|Italy]] became the first goalkeeper to be sent off in a World Cup Finals match, dismissed for handling outside his area against [[Norway national football team|Norway]] in [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]]. His team went on to win 1–0 and reached the [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final|final]] before losing to [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in a penalty shoot-out, in which he became the first goalkeeper ever to stop a penalty in a final shoot-out.
Iker Casillas holds both the record for fewest goals conceded in a European Championship (1, in [[UEFA Euro 2012|2012]]) and the record for longest unbeaten run at a European Championship, beating the previous record held by Dino Zoff.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Javier Estepa|title=Casillas, world record-breaking goalkeeper|url=http://www.marca.com/2012/07/02/en/football/national_teams/1341180644.html|publisher=Marca|accessdate=1 June 2015|date=2 July 2012}}</ref> He also holds the records for most international clean sheets (102) by a male goalkeeper beating the previous record held by [[Edwin van der Sar]] (72), and became the first goalkeeper in history, male or female, to keep 100 clean sheets at international level in 2015; he also shares the overall record for the most international clean sheets along with the U.S. women's national team goalkeeper [[Hope Solo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.fifa.com/news/y=2012/m=5/news=international-feats-and-fitting-farewell-1641297.html|title=International feats and a fitting farewell|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=1 June 2015|date=30 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="100 clean sheets for Spain">{{cite web|url=https://as.com/diarioas/2015/11/13/english/1447451183_829981.html|title=Casillas into three figures – 100 clean sheets for Spain|publisher=as.com|date=13 November 2015|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref> Buffon holds the record for most minutes without conceding a goal in [[UEFA European Championship qualifying|European Championship Qualifying matches]], going 644 minutes without conceding a goal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Buffon, felice per il record di imbattibilità|url=http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/rubriche/calcio/2011/09/07/visualizza_new.html_726941330.html|accessdate=19 August 2013}}</ref>
===Highest fees=== {{As of|August 2018}}, the most expensive goalkeeper of all time was [[Kepa Arrizabalaga]] following his 2018 [[Euro|€]]80 million (£71 million) transfer to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] from [[Athletic Bilbao]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Player !From !To !Fee ([[Pound sterling|£]]) !Fee ([[Euro|€]]) !Year |- |{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Kepa Arrizabalaga]]<ref name=kepa>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45120514|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga: Chelsea sign Athletic Bilbao goalkeeper in world record deal|date=8 August 2018|publisher=bbc.com}}</ref> |{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Athletic Bilbao|Athletic Bilbao]] |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |£71m |[[Euro|€]]80m |2018 |- |{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Alisson (footballer, born 1992)|Alisson]]<ref name=alisson>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44890499|title=Alisson: Liverpool make Brazilian world's most expensive keeper|date=19 July 2018|publisher=bbc.com}}</ref> |{{flagicon|ITA}} [[A.S. revision.text:
{{Infobox women's national cricket team | name = [[Kenya]] | image = Flag of Kenya.svg | caption = Flag of Kenya | coach = [[Lameck Onyango|Lameck Ngoche]] | captain = [[Emily Ruto]] | first_wmatch = 5 January 2006 v Kenya A | asofdate = April 21, 2016 }}
The '''Kenya national women's cricket team''' is the team that represents the country of [[Kenya]] in international [[women's cricket]]. Their first matches were in January 2006 when they played a triangular series against Kenya A and [[Ugandan women's cricket team|Uganda]].
They played in the African regional qualifiers for the 2009 [[Women's Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] in December 2006 against [[Tanzanian women's cricket team|Tanzania]], Uganda and [[Zimbabwean women's cricket team|Zimbabwe]]. They performed poorly in the tournament, finishing in last place. In December 2009,they won the Africa Women Championships under the captainship of [[Emily Ruto]].
In 2008, [[Sarah Bhakita]] scored unbeaten 186 against [[Rwanda]] to emerge the second woman in the world to achieve the feat in an international match. The Kenya Lwomen's Cricket team also participated in the World Cup Qualifiers held in [[Nairobi]] in December 2010, missing an opportunity to represent the continent by negligible scores, having tied with [[Zimbabwe]] at second place. [[South Africa]] who won all their matches and Zimbabwe achieved that feat instead.<ref>[http://www.cricketeurope4.net/CRICKETEUROPE/DATABASE/2007/TOURNAMENTS/WWC/about.shtml African leg pf World Cup Qualifiers]</ref>
In December 2011, the women' team represented the country in [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] at the annual [[Africa Cricket Championships]] finishing fourth after the winners [[Uganda]], [[Tanzania]] and [[Namibia]]. the other participating countries were [[Nigeria]] and [[Sierra Leone]].
In April 2016, they will play in [[2016 ICC Africa Women's World Twenty20]] to qualify for [[2018 ICC Women's World Twenty20]] in [[West Indies]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chronicle.co.zw/zim-steps-up-preps-for-icc-africa-womens-world-t20/|title=Zim steps up preps for ICC Africa Women’s World T20 {{!}} The Chronicle|website=www.chronicle.co.zw|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesportscampus.com/2016041451208/twenty-20/zimbabwe-step-up-preps-for-icc-africa-womens-world-twenty20-qualifier|title=Zimbabwe step up preps for ICC Africa Women’s World Twenty20 Qualifier {{!}} Twenty-20|last=Administrator|website=www.thesportscampus.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref>
In April 2018, the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) granted full [[Women's Twenty20 International]] (WT20I) status to all its members. Therefore, all [[Twenty20]] matches played between Kenya women and another international side after 1 July 2018 will be a full WT20I.<ref name="status">{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/672322 |title=All T20I matches to get international status |work=International Cricket Council |accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref>
==Current squad==
The are the player who played in [[2016 ICC Africa Women's World Twenty20]]:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cricketkenya.co.ke/news_details.php?news_id=225|title=Cricket Kenya News - Cricket Kenya announces squad for the Pepsi ICC Africa Region CWCQ Division 2 T20 qualifiers|website=www.cricketkenya.co.ke|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref>
* Sylvia Kinyua - Captain * Sarah Bhakita * Margaret Banja * Mary Bele * Mercyline Adhiambo * Mary Wambui * Daisy Wairimu * Ruth Mwihaki * Edith Wanjiru * Queentor Aoko * Venesa Adhiambo * Ruth Ambiyo * Esther Wangare * Sharon Juma

* [[Kenyan cricket team|Kenyan men's cricket team]]

page.title: List of most expensive association football transfers

revision.comment: Removed missing image - File was deleted from Wikimedia Commons - 17 November 2018
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Neymar PSG.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Neymar]], currently the most expensive footballer]] The following is a '''list of most expensive association football transfers''', which details the highest [[Transfer (association football)|transfer]] fees ever paid for [[Football player|players]]. As well as the most expensive transfers of all time, the page also lists transfers which broke the world transfer record. The first recorded record transfer was of [[Willie Groves]] from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for £100 in 1893. This occurred just eight years after the introduction of professionalism by [[The Football Association]] in 1885.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2013/aug/30/the-joy-of-six-record-transfers|title=The Joy of Six: record transfers|first1=Barry|last1=Glendenning|first2=Scott|last2=Murray|first3=Rob|last3=Bagchi|first4=Jacob|last4=Steinberg|date=30 August 2013|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}} The current transfer record was set by the transfer of [[Neymar]] from [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] to [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] for €222 million (£198 million) on 3 August 2017.{{cite web|title=Neymar: Paris St-Germain sign Barcelona forward for world record 222m euros|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40762417|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 August 2017}}{{cite press release|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2017-2018/fc-barcelona-communique-on-neymar-jr-buyout-clause|title= FC Barcelona communiqué on Neymar Jr |date=3 August 2017|access-date=3 August 2017|publisher=FC Barcelona}} == Highest fees == Most of the transfers on this list are to clubs under [[UEFA]]'s jurisdiction, and most of the purchasing clubs are from [[England]], [[France]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]]. However, since the mid 2010s two [[China|Chinese]] clubs have paid large fees for three [[Brazil]]ian players. Three players appear on the list twice: [[Neymar]], [[Ángel Di María]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]]. All of the players on the list are of European ([[UEFA]]), South American ([[CONMEBOL]]) and African ([[Confederation of African Football|CAF]]) origin. There are currently no players from the remaining regions - Asia ([[Asian Football Confederation|AFC]]), North America ([[CONCACAF]]) and Oceania ([[Oceania Football Confederation|OFC]]). ''As of 19 July 2018'' {{legend|#FFFFCC|Fee broke the world football transfer record at the time of the transfer}} {{legend|#D0E6FF|Fee broke the national league record at the time of the transfer}} {{legend|#EEDDEE|Fee broke the record for a [[CONMEBOL|South American]] player at the time of the transfer}} {{legend|#D2FFD2|Fee broke the record for an [[Confederation of African Football|African]] player at the time of the transfer}} {{legend|#FFBBBB|Fee broke the record for a teenager at the time of the transfer (at most at the age of 20 years old)}} {{legend|#FFDAB9|Fee broke the record for a goalkeeper at the time of the transfer}} {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" style="width:100%;" |+{{nowrap|Top 50 transfers }} |- ! data-sort-type="number" |{{Tooltip|R|Rank}} !Player !From !To !Position !Fee

transfer to Jiangsu Suning|date=4 February 2016|accessdate=28 June 2016}} |- |- |} '''Notes''' {{notelist}} ==World football transfer record== {{Split section |Association football transfer world record progression|discuss=Talk:List of most expensive association football transfers#Undo ill-advised merge of record progression |date=October 2017}} The first player to ever be transferred for a fee of over £100 was Scottish [[Forward (association football)|striker]] [[Willie Groves]] when he together with [[Jack Reynolds (footballer, born 1869)|Jack Reynolds]] (£50) made the switch from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in [[1893 in association football|1893]], eight years after the legalisation of professionalism in the sport. It took just twelve years for the figure to become £1000, when [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] striker [[Alf Common]] moved to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].{{cite news |last=Proud |first=Keith |url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/history/memories/teesside/3603267.The_player_with_the_Common_touch_/ |title=The player with the Common touch |publisher=The Northern Echo |date=18 August 2008 |accessdate=12 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BpztUQzs?url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/history/memories/teesside/3603267.The_player_with_the_Common_touch_/ |archivedate=1 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23560273 |title=World record football transfer fees |publisher=BBC |date=1 September 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} It was not until [[1928 in association football|1928]] that the first five-figure transfer took place. [[David Jack]] of [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] was the subject of interest from [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], and in order to negotiate the fee down, Arsenal manager [[Herbert Chapman]] got the Bolton representatives [[drunk]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16066822 |title=Arsenal honour Thierry Henry, Tony Adams & Herbert Chapman |publisher=BBC |date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=12 January 2014}}{{cite news |last=Flanagan |first=Chris |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/how-13-other-world-record-transfers-panned-out |title=How 13 other world record transfers panned out |publisher=Four Four Two |date=4 September 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} Subsequently, David Jack was transferred for a world record fee when Arsenal paid £10,890 to Bolton for his services, after Bolton had asked for £13,000, which was double the previous record made when Sunderland signed [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]'s [[Bob Kelly (footballer)|Bob Kelly]] a fee of for £6,500. {{multiple image | footer = [[Diego Maradona]] and [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] were twice transferred for world record fees.{{cite news|last1=Smyth|first1=Rob|title=Ronaldo at 40: Il Fenomeno’s legacy as greatest ever No9, despite dodgy knees|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/sep/17/ronaldo-40-birthday-brazil-greatest-ever-striker|publisher=''The Guardian''|date=17 September 2016|access-date=1 April 2017}} | image1 = | image2 = Ronaldo Cannes (cropped).jpg }} The first player from outside [[Great Britain]] to break the record was [[Bernabé Ferreyra]], a player known as ''La Fiera'' for his powerful shot. His [[1932 in association football|1932]] transfer from [[Club Atlético Tigre|Tigre]] to [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]] cost £23k, and the record would last for 17 years (the longest the record has lasted) until it was broken by Manchester United's sale of [[Johnny Morris (footballer)|Johnny Morris]] to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] for £24k in March 1949. The record was broken seven further times between 1949 and 1961, when [[Luis Suárez Miramontes]] was sold by [[FC Barcelona]] to [[Inter Milan]] for £152k, becoming the first ever player sold for more than £100k. In [[1968 in association football|1968]], [[Pietro Anastasi]] became the first £500k player when [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] purchased him from [[A.S. Varese 1910|Varese]], which was followed seven years later with [[Giuseppe Savoldi]] becoming the first million pound player when he transferred from [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]] to [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]]. After Alf Common and David Jack, the third player to twice be transferred for world record fees is [[Diego Maradona]]. His transfers from [[Boca Juniors]] to Barcelona for £3m, and then to Napoli for £5m, both broke the record in [[1982 in association football|1982]] and [[1984 in association football|1984]] respectively. The most recent is [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] with his record-breaking move from [[PSV Eindhoven]] to Barcelona in 1996 for £13.2m, although [[Alan Shearer]]'s transfer to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle]] broke the record the same summer. A year later [[Inter Milan]] paid £19.5m for Ronaldo and again he became the player with the highest transfer fee. In the space of 61 days in [[1992 in association football|1992]], three transfers broke the record, all by Italian clubs: [[Jean-Pierre Papin]] transferred from [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] to [[A.C. Milan]], becoming the first ever £10m player. Almost immediately, rivals [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] topped that with the signing of [[Gianluca Vialli]] for a fee of £12m from [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]]. Milan then completed the signing of [[Gianluigi Lentini]] for a fee of £13m which stood as the record for three years. The [[1996 in association football|1996]] transfer of [[Alan Shearer]] from [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], for a fee of £15m,{{cite news |last1=Turnbull |first1=Simon |last2=Nixon |first2=Alan |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/shearer-goes-home-for-pounds-15m-1331235.html |title=Shearer goes home for pounds 15m |publisher=The Independent |date=30 July 1996 |accessdate=12 January 2014 |location=London}} kickstarted a year-by-year succession of record breaking transfers: [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] moved [[1997 in association football|the following year]] to [[Inter Milan]] from [[FC Barcelona]] for a fee of £17m,{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-ronaldo-signs-up-for-inter-1257195.html |title=Ronaldo signs up for Inter |publisher=The Independent |date=21 June 1997 |accessdate=12 January 2014 |location=London}} which was followed in [[1998 in association football|1998]] by the shock transfer of his fellow countryman [[Denílson de Oliveira Araújo|Denílson]] from [[São Paulo FC|São Paulo]] to [[Real Betis]] for a fee of approximately £21m.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/france-98-denilson-the-menacing-1163252.html |title=Denilson The Menacing |publisher=The Independent |date=7 June 1998 |accessdate=12 January 2014 |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Longmore}} In [[1999 in association football|1999]] and [[2000 in association football|2000]], Italian clubs returned to their record-breaking ways, with [[Christian Vieri]] transferring from [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] to [[Inter Milan]] for £28m,{{cite news |last=Whyte |first=Derrick |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-inters-pounds-28m-swap-deal-for-lazios-vieri-1099122.html |title=Inter's pounds 28m swap deal for Lazio's Vieri |publisher=The Independent |date=9 June 1999 |accessdate=12 January 2014 |location=London}} while [[Hernán Crespo]]'s transfer from [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] to Lazio ensured he became the first player to cost more than £30m.{{cite web |last=Agnew |first=Paddy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2000/jul/12/newsstory.sport |title=Crespo to join Lazio in record £36m transfer |publisher=The Guardian |date=12 July 2000 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} The transfer prompted the BBC to ask "has the world gone mad"?{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/830192.stm |title=When transfers go mad |publisher=BBC |date=12 July 2000 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} It took two weeks for the record to be broken when [[Luís Figo]] made a controversial £37m move from Barcelona to rivals [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/848836.stm |title=Figo's the Real deal |publisher=BBC|date=24 July 2000|accessdate=1 September 2013}} A year later, Real increased the record again with a signing of [[Zinedine Zidane]] for £48 million (150 billion lire).{{cite web|last1=Ley|first1=John|title=Zidane in £48m Real deal|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/3008694/Zidane-in-48m-Real-deal.html|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=4 August 2017|date=9 July 2001}} Zidane's record stood for 8 years, the longest since the 1940s. Real Madrid continued with the ''Galácticos'' policy by buying [[Kaká]] from [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] for €67 million (£56 million),{{Cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/european/5469863/Real-Madrid-to-confirm-world-record-56m-signing-of-Kaka.html|title = Real Madrid to confirm world record £56m signing of Kaka|date = 7 June 2009|accessdate = 13 February 2015|website = The Telegraph|publisher = |last = Wilson|first = Jeremy}} which was the world record in pound sterling. However, both world record in euro and in pound sterling were broke by Real themselves when signing [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] for £80m (€94m) from [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in [[2009 in association football|the same transfer window]],{{cite web|title=Ronaldo completes record Madrid switch|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=837497.html|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=4 August 2017}} 4 years later Real Madrid broke the record again after completed the signing of [[Gareth Bale]] from [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in [[2013 in association football|2013]]. Although Real initially insisted that the transfer cost €91.59 million, slightly less than the Ronaldo fee, the deal was widely reported to be around €100 million (around £85.1 million).{{cite web|title=Just how much did Bale's transfer to Real Madrid cost?|url=http://www.itv.com/news/wales/2016-01-21/just-how-much-did-bales-transfer-to-real-madrid-cost/|publisher=ITV|accessdate=4 August 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Why Real Madrid think that even €100m for Gareth Bale is not silly money|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/sep/01/gareth-bale-100m-transfer-real-madrid|publisher=The Observer|accessdate=4 August 2017}} Documents leaked in 2016 by [[Football Leaks]] revealed that installments brought the final Bale fee up to a total of €100,759,418.{{cite web|last1=Percy|first1=John|title=Gareth Bale contract leak sparks panic at Real Madrid|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/01/29/gareth-bale-contract-leak-sparks-panic-at-real-madrid/|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=4 August 2017}} In 2016, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] eventually took the record away from Real Madrid, signing French midfielder [[Paul Pogba]] for €105 million (£89 million), {{cite web|title=Paul Pogba: Manchester United re-sign France midfielder for world-record £89m|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37016170|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 August 2017}} four years after having released him to [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] for [[training compensation]]. A year after the Pogba transfer, however, there was a major jump in the record fee. [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris St. Germain]] matched the €222 million buyout fee of [[Barcelona C.F.|Barcelona's]] [[Neymar]], converted to a reported £198 million{{cite web|last1=Wallace|first1=Sam|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/08/03/psg-announce-signing-neymar-barcelona-finally-bow-198m-cheque/|title=Neymar becomes most expensive footballer of all time in £198m move to PSG (paid for with one cheque)|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=4 August 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Lowe|first1=Sid|last2=Laurens|first2=Julien|last3=Hunter|first3=Andy|title=Neymar set to seal world-record move to PSG worth £450m in fees and wages|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/02/neymar-psg-barcelona-tells-team-mates-leave|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=4 August 2017}} or £200 million by different sources. This was the first time that the record fee was paid by a French club. ===Historical progression=== {{Multiple issues|section=y| {{cleanup section|reason=use inflation template|date=August 2017}} {{Original research section|date=July 2018|reason=British pound inflation for transfer fees originally paid in different currencies is meaningless.}} }} Comparison of fees in different nations is complicated by varying [[exchange rate]]s.
