{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} '''Misogyny in sports''' refers to different discourses, actions and [[ideologies]] present in various sporting environments that add, reinforce, or normalize the [[objectification]], degrading, [[shaming]], or absence of women. It can range from limiting women's participation to informal reinforcement of the men's status, by comparing it to that of a woman. Misogyny within sports can also include unfair wages, as well as reduced coverage in sports media. Because sports are so popular in today's society, they can be seen as a microcosm for the way people view their culture.
== Misogyny == Traditionally, the views of women's involvement in sports has led many to believe that they are absent from inclusion altogether. For much of history, most of the discussion around women and sports was centered around health risks for upper-class, white women, while excluding those of non-white or homosexual orientation.<ref name="DD">Daniels, Dayna B. [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/film_and_history/v035/35.1daniels.html You Throw Like a Girl: Sport and Misogyny on the Silver Screen] Film & History (2005): n. pag. Web. 2 March 2015.</ref> As of 2013, female athletes receive an average of 63,000 fewer opportunities than men at [[NCAA]] institutions.<ref name="Women's Sports Foundation 2013">"Women's Sports Foundation." Women's Sports Foundation. Women's Sports Foundation, 18 March 2013. Web. 12 March 2015.</ref>
Women's participation in various sports, such as [[boxing]] or [[rugby union]], has grown in recent years. However, there is still an undertone that they don't belong, by calling into question their sexuality or [[femininity]].<ref name="DD" /> A 1993 study conducted by [[Michael Messner]] found that women were described using words like "girls" and "young women", while men were described using words like "young man" and "men" but never as "boys." The same study found also found instances of women's successes and failures being described as "her little jump hook", adding to the notion that women are less talented or skilled than their male counterparts.<ref>Messner, Michael. "Reflections on Communication and Sport." Reflections on Communication and Sport. Sage Journals, 30 December 2012. Web. 12 March 2015.</ref>
Recent examples of [[Athletes and domestic violence|domestic violence against women in various sports]] have highlighted the deeply rooted [[misogyny]] present in most sports. Similarly, the masculinity that is involved in many sporting activities allow men to assume that they have "the right to vent their anger on the bodies of women and to discriminate against women in a number of different ways, including sexualizing and marginalizing them" says Kath Woodward, Professor of Sociology at the Open University.<ref>Woodward, Kath. "Time to Stop Playing Nice about Misogyny in Sports." The Conversation. Arts and Humanities Research Center, 23 October 2014. Web. 4 May 2015. <http://theconversation.com/time-to-stop-playing-nice-about-misogyny-in-sports-33047></ref>
Many of the messages that are delivered to male sports participants are about being tougher than your opponent, and the toughest one wins. The worst thing to be called or compared to in sports is a woman, and the quickest way to cut someone down. Coaches and pop culture constantly deliver messages that emphasize hyper-masculinity. However, all too often the societal frame of being a man is one that undermines women. These behaviors are seen as normal in the male-dominated sports world.<ref>Fagan, Kate. "RECENT EVENTS EXPOSE SEXISM IN SPORTS CULTURE." ESPN. ESPN Internet Ventures, 14 February 2013. Web. 6 May 2015. <http://espn.go.com/espnw/news-commentary/article/8944124/espnw-recent-events-further-expose-underlying-sexism-sports-culture>.</ref><ref>Bryant, Howard. "Sports' Male Problem." ESPN. ESPN Internet Ventures, 18 April 2013. Web. 6 May 2015. <http://espn.go.com/espn/story/_/id/9183580/sports-male-problem>.</ref><ref>Mooney, David. "The Chilling Reality of Sexism in Football." New Statesman. New Statesman, 30 September 2014. Web. 6 May 2015. <http://www.newstatesman.com/sport/2014/09/chilling-reality-sexism-football>.</ref>
The sexism experienced by women in sports also tends to be more overt, and less subtle, than sexism in other work and organizational settings. Sexist remarks made in many workplaces have been discouraged by displays of social disapproval and the potential threat of organizational reprimand. This has forced misogynistic views to be more subtle in these settings, taking the form of [[microaggressions]] or remarks in the form of [[benevolent sexism]]. In the sports industry, in comparison, overt sexist remarks are still commonplace and tend to result in less public backlash than similar statements given in other settings.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fink|first=Janet|date=Jan 2016|title=Hiding in Plain Sight: The Embedded Nature of Sexism in Sport|url=|journal=Journal of Sport Management|volume=30|issue=1|pages=1–7|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Female athletes do not receive more attention or opportunities as compared to their male counterparts. Misogyny in sports make many people perceive women as weaklings in sporting activities. Recently, the number of females in sports has increased but not in the same percentage with that of males. For example, only fewer women participate in games such as rugby and boxing. In 2015, Don McPherson, a former National Football League (NFL) quarterback, argued that in sports boys are raised not only to be men but also not to be women (California Institute of Integral Studies). In other words, he meant that coaches ensure that young males gain enough strength to face their opponents and discourage these players to fear, which is a character associated with femininity. In sporting activities, to be masculine means to possess skills, energy, and toughness to become the victor in many tournaments. Misogyny in sports is a significant factor that contributes to shaming, objectifying, and degrading women regardless of their performance on the playing field.
==Gender gap== ===Coverage in media=== {{Refimprove section|date=June 2018}}{{Original research section|date=June 2018}}
Misogyny refers to hatred or prejudice towards women. It is manifested in several ways, such as hostility, sex discrimination, and social exclusion. Despite the popularity of sports in many societies in the world, misogyny is still prevalent in sports. In recent times, media coverage has increased the popularity of sports, but women's sports still suffers. It would be expected that both men's and women's sports are equally promoted on the media, such as television, radio and print media. Unfortunately, the coverage of women sports remains lower and shows no signs improvement; hence misogyny in media coverage of women's sports is confirmed.
There is little improvement in the coverage of women's sports by the media. The Women's Sports and Fitness Foundation reports that only 7% percent of media coverage is devoted to women's sport. This is discouraging based on findings that over 60% of sports fans would like to watch women's sport on television. Discouragingly, the media coverage of these sports is dominated by terms, such as older, pregnant, married and unmarried thus shifting the attention from sports. In the same regard, Kelly (1) reports that men are three times likely to be mentioned in sports media than women, in a language that focuses on the sporting aspect and not the aesthetic aspects.
The efforts to popularize women sports through media coverage dependents on the online presence of broadcasters on social media platforms, such as Facebook and Twitter. However, Hull (4) reports that little efforts are being undertaken in respect to the same. A sampling of an estimated twenty thousand tweets involving two hundred broadcasters of local sports in the United States of America showed that only 5% of the tweets were related to women's sports (Hull 5). Besides, the study revealed worrying findings that female sports broadcasters tweeted more on men's sports than women's. Worst of all, the sports broadcasters in larger cities were found to be unlikely to report on women's sports.
Despite the increasing viewership of women's sports, there remains a larger disparity in the sports coverage for men's and women's sports. Findings of a study by the Birmingham University indicates the top six newspaper in Britain had fewer stories on women sports than the previous year when Olympics was taking place. Stories concerning women's sports were outnumbered by the stories on men's sport by twenty times. These newspapers were: The mirror, sun, Times, Mail, Express, Mirror, and Telegraph. The same study explains that a year after the 2012 Olympics, 97% of the sports coverage was on men's sports (Martinson 1). Furthermore, the study went ahead to link this scenario to the shortage of female sports journalists.
Media is influenced by many aspects of society. Equally, sporting activities attracts the attention of many people in the society. Therefore, the perception of the society towards equality and respect to women can be improved through increased coverage of women's sports on the media. The misogyny in the society can be said to be caused by the reluctance of media people to give adequate coverage to women's sports. We cannot be aiming to achieve parity in sports when the media devotes less than 5% of media coverage on women's sports. At the same time, the coverage of the women's sport should focus on sports and not on aesthetics and sexuality. Change is urgently needed to reverse this. This change is welcome because it will influence the societies' perception towards women. Perhaps, more women should be encouraged to develop careers in sports journalism for this to be realized. Despite the existing situation, it is good to remain hopeful that women's sport will be given increased coverage because many fans are would love to see these sports on their screens.
Women's sports have been underrepresented in comparison to men in their respective sports. In 2009, [[SportsCenter]] dedicated only 1.4% of its airtime to women sports, down from 2.2% in 1999.<ref name="Morales, Miguel 2014">Morales, Miguel. "Tennis' Gender Pay Gap Problem Looms On The Sidelines." Forbes. Forbes Magazine, 21 February 2014. Web. 11 March 2015.</ref> In an article published in 2013 by ''[[Science Daily]]'', they pointed out that over 2 years, only 3.6% of articles from five national Sunday papers discussed women sports, compared to 93.8% of articles devoted to men's sports.<ref>Taylor & Francis.[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/09/130918090756.htm Women underrepresented, sexualized in weekend sports reporting] ScienceDaily. ScienceDaily, 18 September 2013.</ref>
Over the course of the NBA (National Basketball Association) and WNBA (Women’s National Basketball Association) in-season and off-season in 2009, a study was done based on the number of stories and airtime each league had. The NBA had 72 stories totaling 66 minutes in-season and 81 stories totaling 51 minutes in the off-season. Which is significantly more than 8 stories at 5.5 minutes in-season, and 0 stories in the off-season for the WNBA. The quality of the stories themselves was significantly lower than the men, including gag stories involving sexual dialogue or emphasizing their bodies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_sports|title=Women’s sports|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikipedia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 September 2018}}</ref> Regarding the games themselves, the women’s had lower quality, editing mistakes, and fewer camera angles.
Research has shown that children start to learn stereotypical attitudes towards gender-appropriate actions at a very early age, and traditional images in print photographs and advertising reinforce typical gender roles. Media plays a powerful role in shaping children's perception, more so than text as children develop a sense of visual literacy earlier than written literacy. A 1990 study concluded that two thirds of photos in reading primers were of men, often shown leading more action-packed, and significant lives than the women depicted in the photographs. Several studies have shown that women are often framed as sexual objects and lesser competitors, as well as displaying more emotion than men, in many sports photographs. Many media studies suggest that they continue to "reinforce the hegemonic image that sport is a right of passage for men." Studies suggest that in Sports Illustrated, which has been labeled the most influential sports publication, men are the preeminent figures featured in photographs and feature articles within the magazine. When women are underrepresented, there is an underlying message being conveyed that they don't belong, don't exist, or have not accomplished anything.<ref>Hardin M, Lynn S, Walsdorf K, Hardin B. The Framing of Sexual Difference in SI for Kids Editorial Photos. Mass Communication & Society [serial online]. Summer2002 2002;5(3):341-359</ref>
In the UK, media talks of re-signing convicted rapist Ched Evans to Sheffield United Football Club.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/29647263</ref> Additionally, misogynistic leaflets were distributed by a rugby team at one of the country’s most prestigious universities, the [[London School of Economics]].<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/10/06/lse-rugby-club-homophobic-sexist-leaflets_n_5937974.html</ref> These are only a few of the most recent examples. Problems with gender persist.<ref>https://theconversation.com/time-to-stop-playing-nice-about-misogyny-in-sports-33047</ref>
Some publicity given to the NFL scandals in the US<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/sep/28/nfl-scandal-american-football-annual-trip-wembley-miami-dolphins-oakland-raiders</ref> and the Oscar Pistorius trial in South Africa<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/feb/22/oscar-pistorius-south-africa-war-women</ref> some argue show the endurance of patriarchal power structures.<ref>https://theconversation.com/women-have-the-chance-to-be-more-than-prostitutes-and-wags-at-this-world-cup-27897</ref> They might be signs of deeply embedded misogyny within sports internationally.<ref>https://theconversation.com/sexism-sport-and-how-blatter-took-his-eye-off-the-ball-again-14863</ref>
=== Pay gap === [[File:Serena Williams (9634023394).jpg|thumb|Serena Williams, the highest paid woman in sports in 2017]] The pay gap in sports seems to arise depending on the gender and the type of sport. Based on athletics data in 2009, female athletes earned 23.4 percent less than male athletes.<ref name="Morales, Miguel 2014" /> In 2014, based on Arsenal's performance data, Arsenal's women soccer team earned less than the men's team. The women's team earned five thousand dollars as opposed to the men's whose pay scale was $1.8 million.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kwakye|first1=Jeanette|date=31 October 2014|title=Female sport stars should earn the same as their male counterparts|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/31/female-sport-stars-male-prize-money|journal=The Guardian|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> This gap does not only apply to athletes, but also to members of the teams coaching staff.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://minnlawyer.com/2016/05/05/u-s-womens-soccer-issues-red-card-to-pay-gap/|title=U.S. women’s soccer issues red card to pay gap|last=Sharma|first=Aalok|date=May 5, 2016|website=Minnlawyer|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 26, 2018}}</ref>
Many studies have been conducted to discover the emergence of the pay gap in sports. An employment strategy conducted in European Union member states shows disparity in pay between male and females.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rubery|first=Jill|date=|title=How to close the gender pay gap in Europe: towards the gender mainstreaming of pay policy|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/j.1468-2338.2005.00353.x|journal=Industrial Relations Journal|volume=36:3|pages=184|via=Wiley}}</ref> The investigation was how players and coaches are paid determined by gender and the sport they participate in. The results showed that the coaches of the male team had a much greater salary than the coaches of the women's team. In 2001, the average salary for coaches of woman's teams in Division 1 was $38,191, while coaches of men's teams earned an average of $61,534.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jacobson|first1=Jennifer|date=2001|title=Female Coaches Lag In Pay And Opportunities To Oversee Men's Teams|issue=Chronicles Of Higher Education|pages=47.39}}</ref> At Division 1 I-FBS Schools in the USA, the median head coaches' salaries were $2,257,600 higher for men in comparison to their women counterparts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.womenssportsfoundation.org/research/article-and-report/elite-athletes/pay-inequity/|title=Pay Inequity in Athletics - Women's Sports Foundation|work=Women's Sports Foundation|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref> A study conducted by Michigan State University found that the salaries for both men and women Division 1 coaches was determined by both gender and type of sport. It showed that coaching males has a more positive impact on a coaches salary than coaching females did, and because of this, both athletic directors and men's coaches have a high interest in maintaining and reinforcing the status quo, which indicates that the lowest paying coaching jobs are held by women.<ref>Knoppers A, Meyer B, Ewing M, Forrest L. Gender and the Salaries of Coaches. Sociology Of Sport Journal [serial online]. December 1989;6(4):348-361.</ref>
On the other hand, tennis remains as the one sport that has the most comparable and fair pay between men and women. Tennis receives the most media coverage than any other women’s sport, and through social media, is continuing to experience growth in popularity. According to Forbes, eight of the top ten best paid women athletes are tennis players.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/08/14/the-highest-paid-female-athletes-2017/#73e01d993d0b|title=Serena Williams Heads The Highest-Paid Female Athletes 2017|last=Badenhausen|first=Kurt|date=August 14, 2017|website=Forbes|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 28, 2018}}</ref> A 2009 research conducted by three professors from Brigham Young University found that male and female tennis players have the same employers at 21 events, including the four grand-slam tournaments ([[Australian Open]], [[French Open]], [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]], [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]]).<ref name=":5">Flake C, Dufur M, Moore E. Advantage men: The sex pay gap in professional tennis. International Review For The Sociology Of Sport [serial online]. June 2013;48(3):366-376.</ref> While, in most other sports, women’s associations have different sponsorships and media coverage.
The 2007 Wimbledon Championships was the first tournament that offered equal prize money for male and female athletes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2015/11/2007-wimbledon-offers-equal-prize-money/56891/|title=2007: WIMBLEDON OFFERS EQUAL PRIZE MONEY|last=Tignor|first=Steve|date=November 28, 2015|website=Tennis|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 28, 2018}}</ref> However, while this may be the case during televised events and the grand slams, women are still not receiving as much in middle- and low- tier events; the most popular rationalization being that men play longer.<ref name=":5" /> Although it is true that men players are required to play a best-of-5 set and that women players are only required to play best-of-3-sets, other than during the grand slams, this does not apply to any other tournaments. Another argument for unequal pay is that men generate more revenue through higher television ratings and attendance. However, most tournament tickets grant spectators access to both men’s and women’s matches on that day. So, aside from counting the numbers of viewers per match, it is difficult to determine revenues in tournaments where both sexes play. Finally, there is also evidence that ratings are mostly equal, with some cases indicating women being higher than men.<ref name=":5" />
Women’s annual median pay gap in the United States was 19% lower than the men.<ref>O'Shannessy, C. (2018). Is Women’s Game Weaker? Nope. Check the Stat Sheet. ''New York Times,167''(58067), D3-D3.</ref> Supporters of the continued wage gap tend to say that men deserve to be paid more because they are stronger and have greater attendance rates. However, when examining statistics, this opinion is unsupported. In the 2015 Open, the men's champion, [[Novak Djokovic]], served a 125 mph serve. [[Serena Williams]] topped this by 1 mph. In 2008 at Wimbledon, the fastest serve in the women’s final was 129 mph, the same as the fastest serve in the men’s final. A fan of unfair pay may say that women deserve to be paid less because their sporting events are less entertaining. However, the main reason for boredom in tennis is long, drawn out points, generally defined as nine rallies or more. In the 2017 open, “long rallies” accounted for 11% of the points in men’s matches, with only about a 1% difference at 12.2% for women. These supporters also like to complain that women tend to use backhands more often than forehands in comparison to men. Both are untrue as backhand winners fall in at 35.7% for women and 30.2% for men.<ref>Flake, C. R., Dufur, M. J., & Moore, E. L. (2012). Advantage men: The sex pay gap in professional tennis. ''International Review for the Sociology of Sport,48''(3), 366-376. doi:10.1177/1012690212442166</ref> According to statistical analysis, women and men’s tennis games are within comparable measures. As for attendance rates, these are difficult to calculate because most tickets for matches are sold as a pair for the women and men’s game. The only true way to determine the audience size would be to do a head count at every match.
There are some who believe that the problem in trying to explain the gender pay gap, is that they are trying to justify why it exists instead of addressing the problem of why it exists in the first place. Karen Farquharson, who is a professor at Australia's Swinburne University of Technology, says the problem is a societal thing that results from not valuing women in the society. Karen admits that women are not strong as men but it does not mean they are not entertaining and competitive. The main reason why they remain less in sports is that the society is patriarchal and male-dominated especially when it comes to sports. This means that sports are like a vicious circle and broadcasters just take advantage of it to only broadcast male games continuously leaving out women thinking they are not interested.<ref name="forbes.com">Morales, Miguel. "Tennis' Gender Pay Gap Problem Looms On The Sidelines." Forbes. Forbes Magazine, 21 February 2014. Web. 5 May 2015. <https://www.forbes.com/sites/miguelmorales/2014/02/21/tennis-gender-pay-gap-problem-looms-on-the-sidelines/>.</ref>
Additionally, female athletes are still not receiving as much non-sexist and positive attention then male athletes. Women sometimes compete under certain conditions that give them less respect than their male peers. Women athletes still face problems of sexual harassment, and over-training associated with eating disorders and body image. The U.S. women’s soccer team, which is ranked much higher than the men’s, enjoy much less recognition, popularity, and pay.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanson|first=Valarie|date=2012|title=The Inequality of Sport: Women < Men|url=https://fisherpub.sjfc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1069&context=ur|journal=The Review: A Journal of Undergraduate Student Research|volume=13|pages=|via=Fisher Digital Publications}}</ref> Such allegations and improper judgment on women have led some players to take a step and sue their federation for discrimination. On 30 March 2016, five top U.S women players, [[Hope Solo]], [[Carli Lloyd]], [[Megan Rapinoe]], [[Alex Morgan]] and [[Becky Sauerbrunn]], filed a lawsuit against the Soccer Federation to demand equal employment opportunity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/01/sports/soccer/uswnt-us-women-carli-lloyd-alex-morgan-hope-solo-complain.html|title=Top Female Players Accuse U.S. Soccer of Wage Discrimination|last=Das|first=Andrew|date=31 March 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=4 April 2016|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The complaint alleges that women on the national soccer team make about 40% of what their male counterparts do.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/money/4277843/us-womens-soccer-equal-pay/|title=MONEY|last=Close|first=Kerry|website=MONEY.com|access-date=4 April 2016}}</ref> Female athletes across all sports may win more trophies and medals, but more often than not, this does not translate to equal payment. Toughness of competition, more lenient rules, and difference in skill levels are just a couple excuses made to disregard this very real social issue.
==Title IX== [[File:Title IX Harassment and Assault Awareness Ribbon.PNG|thumbnail|Title IX Harassment and Assault Awareness Ribbon]] {{Main|Title IX}} Girls and women have been discriminated and denied sports opportunities for quite a long time. For years, women and girls were comfortable with the stereotypes that were attached with the concept of women in sports but with time, different organizations and feminists have come up with strategies to uplift the participation rates of women and girls in sports.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1057/978-1-137-53318-0_4|title="Sporting Females: Power, Diversity and the Body." The Palgrave Handbook of Feminism and Sport, Leisure and Physical Education|last=Francombe-Webb|first=Jessica|last2=Toffoletti|first2=Kim|date=2018|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan, London|year=|isbn=9781137533173|location=|pages=46|language=en|doi=10.1057/978-1-137-53318-0_4}}</ref>
Title IX for example is a legislation that was passed in 1972 to that provided different provisions that protected the rights of equality in sports for women and girls. It is a law that requires all educational programs receiving federal funding to provide equity for both boys and girls. Over the years, the law has been subject to over 20 proposed amendments, reviews, and [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] cases. The law has acted as a way of motivating women and girls to participate more in sports.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1057/978-1-137-53318-0_4|title="Sporting Females: Power, Diversity and the Body." The Palgrave Handbook of Feminism and Sport, Leisure and Physical Education|last=Francombe-Webb|first=Jessica|last2=Toffoletti|first2=Kim|date=2018|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan, London|year=|isbn=9781137533173|location=|pages=50|language=en|doi=10.1057/978-1-137-53318-0_4}}</ref>
The participation of girls and women in sports has brought about numerous immediate and long-term benefits that have a lasting impact on both the female gender and the society at large.<ref name=":4">Guest, Andrew M., and Anne Luijten. "Fan culture and motivation in the context of successful women’s professional team sports: a mixed-methods case study of Portland Thorns fandom." ''Sport in Society'' (2017): 1-18.</ref> Some of the different provisions of the ‘Title IX’ include equality in the different sports fields for both sexes. Essentially, this provision is aimed at placing women at an advantage in athletics and sports. However, it is important that such provisions do not necessarily imply that equal amounts are spent on sports activities and matters for both sexes and athletic opportunities for boys and men to be reduced but simply means that both women and girls should not be discouraged and denied any sports opportunities. But there are still thousands of schools across the county are not in compliance with Title IX.<ref>"Title IX." TitleIX.info. Title IX, n.d. Web. 30 March 2015.</ref> The law covers all educational activities that receive public funding, so even though sports receive little public funding, they are still subject to Title IX, and are the most well-known application of the law. Opponents of the law say that has led to a break down of men's sports, pointing to the number of schools and institutions that have dropped sports since the enactment of Title IX, such as wrestling and cross-country.<ref>Shelton, Donald E. (2001). "Equally Bad is Not Good: Allowing Title IX "Compliance" by the Elimination of Men's Collegiate Sports". University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform</ref><ref>"College Wrestling Scholarships." College Wrestling Scholarships. N.p., n.d. Web. 4 May 2015 <http://www.collegesportsscholarships.com/wrestling.htm></ref>
Prior to the law, only 295,000 girls participated in high school sports and they received only 2% of the athletic budget. In 2016-2017, that number had risen to 3.4 million girls playing high school sports across the country.<ref>"The Next Generation of Title IX." Title IX 40 Years and Counting (2012): n. pag. National Women's Law Center. June 2012. Web. 30 March 2015.</ref><ref>“High School Sports Participation Increases for 28th Straight Year, Nears 8 Million Mark.” ''NFHS'', 6 Sept. 2017, www.nfhs.org/articles/high-school-sports-participation-increases-for-28th-straight-year-nears-8-million-mark/.</ref>
Various studies have found that those who participate in high school athletics have higher wages, educational attainment, and educational aspirations later on in life. The rise in opportunities to participate in sports has led to a similar rise in labor force participation, which leads to more women with positive earnings.<ref>Betsey Stevenson, 2010. "Beyond the Classroom: Using Title IX to Measure the Return to High School Sports," The Review of Economics and Statistics, MIT Press, vol. 92(2), pages 284-301, 08</ref>
Since the enactment of Title IX, women have made strides in college athletics for years. Other factors such as body shaping and fan culture are some of the motivation strategies that concerned individuals in the society are taking up to increase women and girl’s participation in sports.<ref name=":4" /> However, it should be noted that more enforcement strategies need to be put in place to increase women and girl participation in sports since women discrimination in sports has not been completely eradicated since in some cases, women and girl’s participation in sports is not approved.<ref>Kissane, Rebecca Joyce, and Sarah Winslow. "“You’re Underestimating Me and You Shouldn’t” Women’s Agency in Fantasy Sports." ''Gender & Society'' 30.5 (2016): 819-841.</ref>
=== Scholarships === Before the Title IX, Equal Opportunity Law was established, not a single sports scholarship was given women in college sports in the United States. Since then, the number of scholarships given to women has increased each year to almost 85,000 scholarships in 2012, based on the “Number of Available College Athletic Scholarships”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scholarshipstats.com/default.htm|title=Number of Available College Athletic Scholarships|last=O’Rourke|first=Patrick|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Compared to the 92,000 Scholarships available for men in that year.
The Title IX legislation was passed in 1972 and required schools that received federal funding to provide equality for boys and girls. Or having the same amount of male sports teams as women. Because of that, many schools or universities have dropped specific sports teams such as wrestling and men's soccer. Before the law, less than 300,000 girls participated in high school sports, receiving 2% of the sports budget. Since then, that number has increased to over 3.4 million girls playing high school sports across the United States.
== Women's opportunities and their leadership roles == Although Title IX encouraged more women to participate in sports at an NCAA level, the number of women in leadership roles drastically decreased. Women in senior decision making roles devolved to a number of 18% and women in athletic director positions held only 17% in the year 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thesportjournal.org/article/examination-of-gender-equity-and-female-participation-in-sport/|title=Examination of Gender Equity and Female Participation in Sport|last=Senne|first=Joshua A.|date=Feb 26, 2016|website=The Sport Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=Apr 13, 2018}}</ref> Although major strides have been taken by people in all realms of the sports industry to create more opportunities for women, women are still underrepresented in the industry as a whole.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Burton|first=LJ|date=2015|title=Review: Underrepresentation of women in sport leadership: A review of research|url=|journal=Sports Management Review|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> According to the [[NCAA]], only 8.3% of Division I athletics directors are women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/sites/default/files/Final%2B2012%2BCollege%2BRGRC.pdf|title=The 2012 Racial and Gender Report Card: College Sport|last=Lapchick|first=Richard|date=2012|website=NCAA|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Only 21% of college women's athletic programs are headed by women, and women fill only 33% of all administrative jobs in women's programs. In high school, less than 20% of athletic directors are women, and less than 40% of directors of physical education are women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.feminist.org/research/sports/sports3.html|title=Empowering Women in Sports|last=|first=|date=1995|website=Feminist Majority Foundation|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> An American Society of New Editors (ASNE) newsroom census report in 1991 showed 63.1% of newsroom were men and 36.9% were women. In 2012, the percentages had not changed. By 2013, the statistics were slightly worse, showing 63.7% were men and 36.3% were women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.poynter.org/2014/media-is-failing-women-sports-journalism-particularly-so/240240/|title=Media is 'failing women' — sports journalism particularly so|last=Morrison|first=Sara|date=19 February 2014|website=Poynter|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Some issues still remaining in terms of gender inequality in sport include the pay gap discrepancies, lack of opportunities for women in a male dominant industry, and lack of media coverage for women athletes. While there are women who enter top management positions in this industry, men typically receive a greater number of opportunities. Hegemony is described as a state of a “ruling class” referring to men at the forefront of society. This concept reaffirms the status quo that men demand authority in a society from imposition, manipulation, and even consent from certain groups. Due to this restricting concept, women find it much harder to advance in leadership roles simply due to what has already been set in motion by previous generations and previous cultures.
A [http://web.b.ebscohost.com.libezp.lib.lsu.edu/ehost/detail/detail?sid=72b6bdee-2501-4ae7-804d-b181239f9612%40sessionmgr115&vid=0&hid=102&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZSZzY29wZT1zaXRl&preview=false#AN=1536517&db=ecn study] conducted by Alice Eagly and Steven Karau, two professors of psychology and management, explored the [[social role theory]] and [[role congruity theory]] in relation to how women and men assume different career and social roles based on societal expectations. Through the role congruity theory, Eagly and Karau explained similarities between gender roles and leadership roles, which suggested prejudice toward female leader and potential leaders take two forms. "The first form showed a less favorable evaluation of women's potential for leadership because leadership ability is more stereotypical of men than women. The second form showed a less favorable evaluation of the actual leadership behavior of women than men because such behavior is perceived less desirable in women than men."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Whisenant|first=Warren|date=2015|title=Role Congruity Theory: Perceptions of Fairness and Sexism in Sport Management|url=http://libezp.lib.lsu.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=ecn&AN=1536517&site=ehost-live&scope=site|journal=EconLit|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> This research established view points and supportive information on why there are less women in leadership roles than men throughout the sport industry.
The issues women face in sports off the field are not only unique to the United States, and as the spectrum broadens, one can see that the disparity of women in sports governance positions decreases. Some have suggested to require quotas for women to participate in governance of sports programs, but even this solution is flawed. Suggesting that a company makes requirements in their recruitment to seek out women would only be done to achieve a certain number, and not because they actually want to do so in the first place. Instead, these organizations should focus on achieving targets that come close to a standard of around 40% of women representation. This number has been positively associated with correct board governance and effectiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adriaanse|first=Johanna|date=2014|title=The Impact of Gender Quotas on Gender Equality in Sport Governance|url=http://eige.europa.eu/resources/2014_Genderquotasandgenderequalityinsportgovernance.pdf|journal=Journal of Sports Management|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Sexual harassment in the workplace == In her book, "Sexual Harassment in the Workplace", Mary Boland argues that [[sexual harassment]] is a personal attack on a woman's mind and body, that installs fear and violates her right to bodily integrity education, and freedom of movement.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Sexual Harassment in the Workplace|last=Boland|first=Mary|publisher=Sphinx Publications|year=2005|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> According to the ''National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)'' "working women face higher risks than men from job-related stress, and one of the most noxious stressors sexual harassment."<ref name=":2" /> In reference to the toll that it takes on women, Boland states "victims suffer physical, mental, emotional, and financial losses that can be devastating."<ref name=":2" /> According to a study conducted by the Journal of Sport Management, over 50% of 112 respondents reported they encountered some form of sexual harassment over the past 12 months prior to the study.<ref name=":1" /> As reported by the Institute for Diversity and Ethics in Sport at the University of Central Florida in 2012, 90% of sports editors and 88% of sports reporters are men.<ref name=":0" /> The disproportion between men and women in this position may discourage female sport media print professionals from reporting such incidents of sexual harassment according to an article published by Christina Coleburn.<ref name=":0" />
Regardless of the field in which women work, sexual harassment in the workplace is alive and well and in the [[Sport industry|sports industry]], it is common. Women in powerful or governance position are often viewed as too assertive, thus receiving harassment for challenging the preconceived notion of a hierarchy. These women in power also report more instances of sexual harassment in the workplace, because of their threat to the status quo. Studies also suggest that a women in a supervisor position will report more instances of sexual harassment due to their intelligence, knowledge, and experience in a workplace environment where they hold power. Targets of sexual harassment are more likely to be female because they may have masculine tendencies, and men feel the need to reassure their “masculine dominance”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mclaughlin|first=Heather|date=2012|title=Sexual Harassment, Workplace Authority, and the Paradox of Power|url=|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=|pages=625–647|via=}}</ref> The lack of awareness of sexual harassment in the sports industry is extremely concerning for progressive movements towards equality. A study done in 2011 in Quebec called “Disclosure of Sexual Abuse in Sport Organizations: A Case Study” points to the many problems in sports organizations. Most instances point to women rarely, if ever, reporting assault or harassment in the sports business. Most coaches, athletes, and administrators were not even aware of existing protocols of sexual harassment. When questioned about this concerning issue, the administrators resorted back to their lawyers; assuming that the issue was for too complicated to tackle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=endsexualexploitation.org/articles/sexual-exploitation-sports-industry-abuse-power/|title=Sexual Exploitation in the Sports Industry: An Abuse of Power|last=Urie|first=Marie|date=2018|website=endsexualexploitation.org|publisher=National Center on Sexual Exploitation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The [[USA Gymnastics sex abuse scandal]] that occurred over the course of several years, but came to light in the latter months of 2017 and early 2018 involved former doctor [[Larry Nassar]]. More than 250 young women accused Nassar of sexual harassment and abuse. Many of these women were seen and treated by Nassar as a gymnast. Because of his role as the USA gymnastics team doctor, Nassar was able to be alone with hundreds of young women and girls over the course of nearly two decades. Women can often be afraid to come forward with these allegations because of how it may affect their career and how others may see them afterwards. [[Aly Raisman]], a USA Gymnast, explained how the abuse from Nassar had occurred from such a young age, that despite strange thoughts about his treatment methods, she was taught to trust him which is why it took so long to figure out what was happening to her and many other gymnasts and come forward about it.<ref>LaPook, J., Dr. (2018, September 9). Aly Raisman, one of the most accomplished American gymnasts of all time. ''60 Minutes [CBS]''. Available from NewsBank: <nowiki>https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/document-view?p=AWNB&docref=news/16E5E695379A3120</nowiki>.</ref>
According to associate director of research at Pew Research Center, Katie Simmons, "a woman's main role has always been to be a wife, and then a mother. Women have been stereotyped for years as being the less intellectual and weaker sex."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Simmons|first=Katie|date=2011|title=Women in Top Management Positions in the Sport Industry: Breaking Down the Barriers and Stereotypes|url=http://fisherpub.sjfc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1031&context=sport_undergrad|journal=Sport Management Undergraduate|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Women are often objectified in the sport industry, and judged solely on the way they look, especially now when social media has become more and more mainstream. Discussed in the article ''Sports Journalism Has A Major Sexual Harassment Problem,'' women working in the sport industry infrequently report incidents where they have experienced sexual harassment and inappropriate comments throughout their careers due to fear or losing their job.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.slantnews.com/story/2015-08-17-sports-journalism-has-a-major-sexual-harassment-problem|title=Sports Journalism Has A Major Sexual Harassment Problem|last=Coleburn|first=Christina|date=|website=Slant News|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507231958/https://www.slantnews.com/story/2015-08-17-sports-journalism-has-a-major-sexual-harassment-problem|archivedate=7 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> One occupation that frequently experiences sexual harassment in the sport industry are female sport media print professionals.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Pederson|first=Paul|date=2014|title=Management and Marketing Research An Examination of the Perceptions of Sexual Harassment by Sport Print Media Professionals|url=http://journals.humankinetics.com/jsm-back-issues/jsmvolume23issue3may/anexaminationoftheperceptionsofsexualharassmentbysportprintmediaprofessionals|journal=Journal of Sport Management|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Female sport media print professionals are typically sports editors, sportswriters, sports columnists, and sports reporters.Women working in this sector of the sport industry have reported numerous incidents where they have experienced threatening comments, sexual abuse and harassment, or some form of intimidation.
==See also== *[[Misogyny in hip hop culture]] *[[Women's sports]]

First held in 2003, the competition expanded and now includes a [[half marathon]] race along with the main race.[http://www.iaaf.org/news/report/kibet-breaks-nairobi-marathon-record Kibet breaks Nairobi Marathon record] It was part of "[[The Greatest Race on Earth]]", fully sponsored by [[Standard Chartered|Standard Chartered Bank]]. The other three legs of this four-marathon race were the [[Hong Kong Marathon]], the [[Mumbai Marathon]] and the [[Singapore Marathon]]. ==Past winners== ===Marathon=== [[File:Alice Chelangat at the revision.text:
[[File:Greek vase with runners at the panathenaic games 530 bC.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Ancient Greek race at the [[Panathenaic Games]], illustrated on a Greek vase. Like the [[Isthmian Games]] of [[Corinth]], the Panathenaic Games continued into early Christian times.<ref>Susan Heuck Allen, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=rV8vyYn-qMgC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39 Finding the walls of Troy: Frank Calvert and Heinrich Schliemann at Hisarlík]'', University of California Press, 1999, {{ISBN|0-520-20868-4}}, p. 39.</ref>]] The '''New Testament''' uses a number of '''[[Sportsperson|athletic]] [[metaphor]]s''' in discussing Christianity, especially in the [[Pauline epistles]] and the [[Epistle to the Hebrews]]. Such metaphors also appear in the writings of contemporary philosophers, such as [[Epictetus]] and [[Philo]],<ref>Anthony C. Thiselton, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=aNkcqC9bdAMC&pg=PA713 The First Epistle to the Corinthians: A commentary on the Greek text]'', Eerdmans, 2000, {{ISBN|0-8028-2449-8}}, p. 713.</ref> drawing on the tradition of the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]],<ref>David Arthur DeSilva, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=y9GA4JRq9AEC&pg=PA362 Perseverance in Gratitude: A socio-rhetorical commentary on the Epistle "to the Hebrews"]'', Eerdmans, 2000, {{ISBN|0-8028-4188-0}}, p. 362.</ref> and this may have influenced New Testament use of the imagery.<ref>Roman Garrison, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=HrJAe31jayUC&pg=PA104 The Graeco-Roman Context of Early Christian Literature]'', Continuum International Publishing Group, 1997, {{ISBN|1-85075-646-5}}, p. 104.</ref>
The metaphor of running a race "with perseverance" appears in [[Epistle to the Hebrews|Hebrews]] 12:1,<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Hebrews+12:1&version=NIV Hebrews 12:1, NIV (BibleGateway)]: "Therefore, since we are surrounded by such a great cloud of witnesses, let us throw off everything that hinders and the sin that so easily entangles, and let us run with perseverance the race marked out for us."</ref> and related metaphors appear in [[Epistle to the Philippians|Philippians]] 2:16,<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Philippians+2:16&version=NIV Philippians 2:16, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref> [[Epistle to the Galatians|Galatians]] 2:2,<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Galatians+2:2&version=NIV Galatians 2:2, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref> and Galatians 5:7.<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Galatians+5:7&version=NIV Galatians 5:7, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref> In [[Second Epistle to Timothy|2 Timothy]] 4:7, Paul writes "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith."<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2%20Timothy%204:7&version=NIV 2 Timothy 4:7, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref>
In [[First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Corinthians]] 9:24–26,<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1%20Corinthians%209:24-26&version=NIV 1 Corinthians 9:24–26, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref> written to the city that hosted the [[Isthmian Games]],<ref>[[Leland Ryken]], Jim Wilhoit, [[Tremper Longman]], Colin Duriez, Douglas Penney, and Daniel G. Reid, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=qjEYEjVVEosC&pg=RA4-PA693 Dictionary of Biblical Imagery]'', InterVarsity Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8308-1451-5}}, p. 693 (RACE).</ref> the metaphor is extended from running to other games, such as [[Ancient Greek boxing|boxing]],<ref>John Phillips, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=c4F0l2b1QnkC&pg=200 Exploring 1 Corinthians: An expository commentary]'', Kregel Publications, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8254-3495-5}}, p. 200.</ref> to make the point that winning a prize requires discipline, self-control, and coordinated activity.<ref>Jerome H. Neyrey and Bruce J. Malina, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=J7AtGEmOD38C&pg=PA144 Paul, in Other Words: A Culture Reading of His Letters]'', Westminster John Knox Press, 1990, {{ISBN|0-664-22159-9}}, p. 144.</ref> In [[Second Epistle to Timothy|2 Timothy]] 2:5<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2%20Timothy%202:5&version=NIV 2 Timothy 2:5, NIV (BibleGateway).]</ref> the same point is made.<ref>John Norman Davidson Kelly, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=t84kfQfTB50C&pg=PA176 A Commentary on the Pastoral Epistles: I Timothy, II Timothy, Titus]'', Part 1, Continuum International Publishing Group, 1963, {{ISBN|0-7136-1366-1}}, p. 176.</ref> These athletic metaphors are also echoed in later Christian writing.<ref>Jason König, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=WypKKCGev2wC&pg=PA133 Athletics and Literature in the Roman Empire]'', Cambridge University Press, 2005, {{ISBN|0-521-83845-2}}, p. 133.</ref>
As with [[New Testament military metaphors]], these metaphors appear in many hymns, such as ''Fight the Good Fight with All Thy Might'',<ref>[http://www.hymntime.com/tch/htm/f/i/fightthe.htm The Cyber Hymnal: ''Fight the Good Fight with All Thy Might'']: "Run the straight race through God’s good grace."</ref> which was sung in the film ''[[Chariots of Fire]]''; and "[[Angel Band (song)|Angel Band]]",<ref>[http://www.hymntime.com/tch/htm/m/y/mylatest.htm The Cyber Hymnal: ''My Latest Sun Is Sinking Fast'']: "My race is nearly run; / My strongest trials now are past, / My triumph is begun."</ref> which was sung in the film ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]''.
New Testament athletic metaphors were embraced by advocates of [[muscular Christianity]], both in the [[Victorian era]] and in later times.<ref>Richard G. Kyle, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2fRFi2ZPBVkC&pg=PA203 Evangelicalism: An Americanized Christianity]'', Transaction Publishers, 2006, {{ISBN|0-7658-0324-0}}, p. 203.</ref><ref>Dane S. Claussen (ed), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=sYc2dfSbwXMC&pg=PA194 The Promise Keepers: Essays on masculinity and Christianity]'', McFarland, 2000, {{ISBN|0-7864-0700-X}}, p. 194.</ref>
==See also== * [[New Testament military metaphors]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:New Testament content|Athletic]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to sport]] [[Category:Christianity and sports]]

revision.text:
{{for|a list of proprietary cartridges|Nosler proprietary cartridges}} {{Infobox company | name = Nosler | logo = Nosler-logo.jpg | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1948}} | founder = John A. Nosler | defunct = | location_city = [[Bend, Oregon|Bend]], Oregon | location_country = [[United States|US]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | industry = [[Ammunition]] | products = [[Ammunition]], [[handloading]] components, [[Firearm]]s, [[Bullets]], [[Brass]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner =Bob Nosler | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = Nosler, Inc., Nosler Custom, Nosler Reloading | subsid = | homepage = http://www.nosler.com/ | footnotes = }} The name '''Nosler''' applies to a number of companies involved in the manufacture of [[ammunition]] and [[handloading]] components, specializing in high performance [[hollow point bullet|hollow point]] and [[soft point bullet|soft point]] hunting bullets. Current companies include '''Nosler, Inc.''', '''Nosler Custom''', and '''Nosler Reloading'''. Nosler's contributions include both new bullet designs and new manufacturing techniques used in their production.
==Early history== [[John Nosler]] was born 4 April 1913 in [[Brawley, California|Brawley]], California. Nosler was hunting [[moose]] in [[British Columbia]] in 1946, when the bullets he was using failed to penetrate deeply enough to reach vital organs and kill the animal quickly.<ref name="carter">Aaron Carter "John A. Nosler" ''American Rifleman'' January 2011 pp.38-39</ref> At the time, most jacketed bullets employed a single [[copper]] alloy envelope (the jacket) around a single [[lead]] alloy core. The jacket on most military bullets was closed in front and opened at the base. These [[full metal jacket bullet]]s offered good penetration, but often failed to expand and passed completely through an animal leaving a comparatively small wound. Soft-point hunting bullets like Nosler was using had the jacket applied in the opposite direction to completely cover the base, but open at the nose. These bullets would expand to leave a large wound channel, but sometimes broke into small pieces with inadequate momentum to overcome resistance of moving through bone or muscle tissue.
The experience inspired Nosler to develop a new bullet design, intended to expand readily at low impact velocities yet maintain integrity at high impact velocities (see [[terminal ballistics]]). These ''Nosler Partition'' bullets used a specially designed jacket enclosing two separate lead alloy cores.<ref name="carter"/> The front core was open on the nose to expand easily, but expansion would stop at the partition (which was a solid layer of copper extending right across the bullet, not just the thin shell of copper which composed the jacket). The portion of the bullet behind the partition has the structural integrity of a full metal jacket bullet, but the expanded forward jacket leaves a larger wound channel. Bullets were originally manufactured for personal use, using hand made, [[Lathe (metal)|lathe]] turned jackets. In 1948 Nosler began to sell the partition bullets commercially, forming Nosler, Inc.<ref name="nosler">{{cite web|url=http://www.nosler.com/partition-bullet/|title=Partition|publisher=Nosler|accessdate=2010-12-23}}</ref>
Further innovations by Nosler included new techniques of manufacturing bullet jackets that yielded more consistent expansion, better core bonding techniques to prevent separation of the [[lead]] core from the [[copper]] jacket, and the plastic Ballistic Tip used to provide the streamlined shape of a Spitzer boat tail, with the expansion of a hollow point.<ref name="carter"/> The Nosler Ballistic Tip design has been copied by other manufacturers, such as the V-Max bullet by [[Hornady]]. John Nosler sold the production facilities to his son in 1988, and died at his home in Bend, Oregon, on 10 October 2010.<ref name="carter"/>
==Company Information== Today, Nosler makes a number of different hunting bullets for rifle, handgun, and muzzle-loaders. They also manufacture brass and sell loaded ammunition, and Nosler Custom has recently begun to sell limited edition and semi-custom hunting rifles. The original Partition design bullet still is the company's flagship product. It has undergone many refinements over the years, but the basic design concept has remained unchanged.
==Company News== Nosler experienced a massive explosion at their plant in Bend, Oregon on 2 June 2010. No one was harmed in the blast.<ref>[http://www.ktvz.com/news/Nosler-Finds-Some-Good-News-in-Blast-s-Wake/-/413192/625540/-/p4qqvp/-/index.html KTVZ report on Nosler Explosion]</ref>
In February 2015, Nosler announced plans to expand their long-standing operations in Bend, Oregon to their neighboring city of Redmond, where the company purchased 60 acres of undeveloped land in December 2014. Construction of a 30,000 sq. ft. building is planned for completion in 2016 and will house Nosler’s growing ammunition and cartridge brass operations, including the manufacturing of their SSA by Nosler product line based on the company’s acquisition of Silver State Armory in 2013. The expansion is expected to add approximately 20 jobs in Central Oregon and will allow the original Bend plant to focus exclusively on bullet production.<ref name="Redmond thrilled by Nosler expansion plans">{{cite web|title=Redmond thrilled by Nosler expansion plans|url=http://www.bendbulletin.com/business/2851182-151/redmond-thrilled-by-nosler-expansion-plans|publisher=[[The Bulletin (Bend)]]|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="Nosler Ammunition Acquires Silver State Armory">{{cite web|title=Nosler Ammunition Acquires Silver State Armory|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2013/06/nosler-ammunition-acquires-silver-state-armory/#axzz3hIfs39J5|publisher=AmmoLand|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
==Company Developments== In 2006 Nosler announced its very first rifle offering, the Model 48 Trophy Grade.<ref name="Nosler Model 48 Patriot Review">{{cite web|title=Nosler Model 48 Patriot Review|url=http://www.rifleshootermag.com/longrange/nosler-model-48-patriot-review|publisher=RifleShooter |accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
Nosler announced the company’s first proprietary cartridge, the [[26 Nosler]], as the world’s most powerful 6.5mm cartridge commercially available during [[SHOT Show]] in January 2014. In January 2015, Nosler introduced the company’s second cartridge, the 28 Nosler, a 7mm rifle cartridge based on the [[26 Nosler]] case. Since their release, the [[26 Nosler]] and [[28 Nosler]] <ref name="The Firearm Blog">{{cite web|title=Nosler Introduces "World’s Most Powerful" 7mm: The .28 Nosler|url=http://www.thefirearmblog.com/blog/2015/01/30/nosler-introduces-worlds-powerful-7mm-28-nosler/|publisher=The Firearm Blog |accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> have been known for high muzzle velocities and extremely flat trajectories. The parent case for both cartridges is based on the [[.404 Jeffery]] case.
In October 2014, Nosler introduced Ballistic Tip Ammunition as the latest product offering in their factory loaded ammunition.<ref name="AmmoLand: Shooting Sports News">{{cite web|title=Nosler Announces BT Ammunition for America’s Most Popular Game|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2014/10/nosler-bt-ammunition/#axzz3W5Apv0r0|publisher=AmmoLand |accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> The ammunition is loaded exclusively with Nosler’s line of Ballistic Tip hunting bullets, a polymer-tipped projectile made popular by the company when introduced in 1984 as a premium choice for hunting medium-sized game such as deer, antelope and wild hogs.<ref name="North American Hunter">{{cite web|title=Designed For America's Most Popular Game|url=http://www.scout.com/outdoors/hunting/story/1475010-designed-for-america-s-most-popular-game?s=77|publisher=North American Hunter Staff |accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> The Ballistic Tip Ammunition line pairs the performance of the Ballistic Tip projectile with Nosler’s own component brass.
Late 2014 Nosler revamped the Model 48 line. It did away with the Trophy Grade Rifle and replaced it with the Patriot Rifle. The new rifle has a Basix trigger and Bell and Carlson stock. For the most accuracy out of the Patriot, Nosler incorporated an aluminum bedding chassis into the aramid-fiber reinforced carbon fiber stock, and the barrel is free-floated. The stock is a hand laid-up laminate that is elephant gray with black epoxy webbed over the surface. Which means it’s never going to warp or crack. The comb is straight with a pancake cheekpiece and a thick, solid pistol grip. The Patriot rifle chambered in [[.26 Nosler]] should be an effective hunting combination from the mountains to the prairies.<ref name="Nosler Model 48 Patriot Review"/>
Early 2016 Nosler introduced its third cartridge the [[.30 Nosler]].
October 2016 Nosler introduces a new line of Competition / Target Bullets - RDF Bullets<ref name="Nosler">{{cite web|title=Nosler Unveils Ultra-High BC, Reduced Drag Factor (RDF) Bullet Line|url=http://www.nosler.com/blog/news-and-articles/2016/10/21/nosler-unveils-ultra-high-bc-reduced-drag-factor-rdf-bullet-line|publisher=Nosler Inc |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref>
October 2016 Nosler introduces the [[.33 Nosler]]<ref name="AmmoLand">{{cite web|title=Nosler Introduces Their Most Powerful Cartridge Yet – The 33 Nosler|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2016/10/nosler-introduces-their-most-powerful-cartridge-yet-the-33-nosler|publisher=AmmoLand |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref>
January 2017 Nosler introduces the [[.22 Nosler]].
==Company Awards== 2007 NRA Golden Bullseye Pioneer Award: John A. Nosler<ref name="Remembering Bullet Innovator John Nosler">{{cite web|title=Remembering Bullet Innovator John Nosler|url=http://www.shootingillustrated.com/articles/2010/10/20/remembering-bullet-innovator-john-nosler/|publisher=Shooting Illustrated |accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
2007 Field and Streams Best of the Best: Nosler Model 48 Rifles<ref name="Nosler History">{{cite web|title=Nosler History|url=http://www.nosler.com/nosler-history/|publisher=Nosler |accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref>
2010 Gray's Sporting Journal - Gray's Best Award: Nosler Model 48 Sporter Rifle<ref name="Nosler History"/>
2010 Field and Streams Best of the Best: Model 48 Trophy Grade Rifle<ref name="Petzal's Picks: The New Best Rifles, Scopes, and Binoculars of 2010">{{cite web|title=Petzal's Picks: The New Best Rifles, Scopes, and Binoculars of 2010 Nosler|url=http://www.fieldandstream.com/photos/gallery/hunting/2010/02/petzals-picks-new-best-rifles-scopes-and-binoculars-2010|publisher=Field & Stream |accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref>
2010 Field and Streams Best of the Best: Trophy Grade BT Lead Free Ammunition
2011 American Rifleman Golden Bullseye Rifle of the Year Award: Nosler Trophy Grade Rifle<ref name="Nosler History"/>
2014 Outdoor Life Editors Choice Award: Nosler M48 Patriot Rifle<ref name="Outdoor Life Best New Rifles">{{cite web|title=2014 Gun Test: OL Reviews and Ranks the Best New Rifles|url=http://www.outdoorlife.com/blogs/gun-shots/2014/05/2014-gun-test-ol-reviews-and-ranks-best-new-rifles|publisher=Outdoor Life |accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
2015 American Rifleman Golden Bullseye Award: Best Ammunition, 26 Nosler <ref name="American Hunter">{{cite web|title=Outdoor Channel Unveils the Winners of the 15th Annual Golden Moose Awards|url=http://www.americanhunter.org/articles/2015/1/12/2015-golden-bullseye-award-winners/|publisher=NRA Staff |accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref>
2015 Outdoor Channel Golden Moose Award: Best Commercial, Flat Out. Lights Out.<ref name="Outdoor Channel">{{cite web|title=2015 Golden Bullseye Award Winners|url=http://outdoorchannel.com/eventstory.aspx?event-id=27888&article-id=28251&articletype=article&key=Outdoor-Channel-Unveils-the-Winners-of-the-15th-Annual-Golden-Moose-Awards|publisher=Outdoor Channel |accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref>
2015 Guns and Shooting Online: Rifle Award - Nosler M48 Heritage Rifle<ref name="Guns and Shooting Online">{{cite web|title=Guns and Shooting Online 2015 Awards|url=http://www.chuckhawks.com/g-s_2015_award.html|publisher=Chuck Hawks |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
2016 Sporting Classics: Company of the Year - Nosler Inc.<ref name="Sporting Classics Daily">{{cite web|title=Sporting Classics Names its 2015 "Award of Excellence" Recipients|url=http://sportingclassicsdaily.com/awards-of-excellence-2015/|publisher=Sporting Classics |accessdate=4 April 2016}}</ref>

They play in the [[Championnat de Maurice D3]]. In 2001 the team has won the [[Mauritian League]].http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/mauri01.html ==Stadium== Their home stadium is [[Maryse Justin Stadium]] (cap. 3,000), located in [[Moka]]. ==Honours== *[[Mauritian League]]:2001 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[[:fr:Olympique de Moka]] *[http://dailytrackpic.wordpress.com/2013/02/06/maryse-justin-stadium-moka-mauritius/] {{Mauritian League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Mauritius]] {{Mauritius-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Qianball court.jpg|thumb|Qianball court]] '''Qianball''' is a racket sport similar to [[tennis]] or [[Squash (sport)|squash]]. The game can be described as a mix between tennis and squash or as squash without walls. The game can be played by two or four players, or used as practice by a single person. '''Qianball''' can be played on any flat hard surface, indoors or outdoors no matter the weather.
The game is played on a [[court]] a little smaller than a tennis court with both players placed on the same side of the net. The player side of the net measures 7.6 * 7.8 m, and the other side of the net should be app. 10 * 12 m, but there are no exact rules for this.
The name is derived from the Chinese Qianlongball, from where the game originates.
The game involves:
*One court measuring 7.6 by 7.8 meters in the player zone and 10 by 12 meters in the ball zone *Two or four players playing respectively single or double *One ballbag with weight or floor embedded hook *A qianball racket for each player *A qianball ball with rubber band *A net or similar at a height of 81 cm
The game is played by placing the ball bag 2.1 m from the net in the so-called Qianball point. the end of the rubber band is attached to the turning rings or the floor embedded hook. The players are positioned on the same side of the net as in [[Squash (sport)|squash]] and takes turns to serve 2 consecutive serves before changing sides. The game is decided in three sets to 15 playing with a running score.
The ball may not touch the ground in the player zone or the opposing player will score a point, and may only touch the ground once in the ball zone.
Denmark was the first country in Europe where Qianball came to from China. In Denmark the game is organised under [[KFUM]] (Danish branch of [[YMCA]] sport). In China there are roughly one million players.
[[Category:Racquet sports]] [[Category:Forms of tennis]] [[Category:Sports originating in China]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stadio Renato Dall'Ara | nickname = | image = BolognaStadioRenatoDallAra.JPG | location = [[Bologna]], Italy| broke_ground = 1925| opened = 1927| renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Bologna Football Club 1909]]| operator = | surface = Grass
105x68m| construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Stadio Littoriale (1927–1945)
Stadio Comunale (1945–1983)| tenants =
[[Bologna F.C. 1909]] (1927-present)
[[Italy national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 38,279| }} '''Stadio Renato Dall'Ara''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Bologna]], Italy. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches and the home of [[Bologna F.C. 1909]]. The stadium was built in 1927 and holds 38,279. It has also been named '''Stadio Littoriale'''. It replaced the [[Stadio Sterlino]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bolognafc.it/stadio.asp|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729135218/http://www.bolognafc.it/stadio.asp|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-07-29|title=Stadio Renato Dall'Ara}}{{it icon}} accessed 09 September 2015 It was one of the host stadiums during the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. The last match of the tournament played there was the [[1990 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#England vs Belgium|England vs Belgium]] match in the Round of 16 which ended 1–0 courtesy of an extra-time goal scored by [[David Platt (footballer)|David Platt]] in the 119th minute.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/90full.html|title=World Cup 1990|accessdate=9 September 2015}} ==International fixtures== The [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA – Group 2)|17 November 1993 qualifier]] between San Marino and England finished with England winning 7–1, but only after the hosts scored in the opening seconds of the match.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/19900296|title=Davide Gualtieri: The man from San Marino who shocked England}} accessed 09 September 2015 The stadium also hosted three international [[rugby union]] test match in 1995, [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]] vs. [[All Blacks]] (the All Blacks won the game 70–6), in 1997 [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]] vs. [[Springboks]] (the Springboks won the game)and [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]] vs. Ireland (Italy won the game). The stadium features as the lead song on the [[Los Campesinos!|Los Campesinos]] album '[http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/22926-sick-scenes/ Sick Scenes]'. [[File:Prepartita bologna bari.jpg|centre|thumb|500px|Panorama of Stadio Renato Dall'Ara]] ==1990 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. The stadium was witness to the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] competition's quickest goal ever scored, by [[Davide Gualtieri]] of [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]], taking 8.3 seconds to put his team ahead against [[England national football team|England]]. It hosted the following matches: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round |- |1990-06-09||{{fb|UAE}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2||{{fb|COL}}||Group D |- |1990-06-14||{{fb|YUG}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fb|COL}}||Group D |- |1990-06-19||{{fb|YUG}}||style="text-align:center;"|4–1||{{fb|UAE}}||Group D |- |1990-06-26||{{fb|ENG}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0 (a.e.t.)||{{fb|BEL}}||Round of 16 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130121145931/http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/europe/italy/emiglia_romagna/bologna_ara.shtml World Stadiums Article] *[http://www.stadiumguide.com/renatodallara/ Stadium Guide Article] *[http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/stadio-renato-dall%27ara-s1918 Stadium Journey Article] {{Bologna F.C. 1909}} {{1934 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{World Cup 1990 stadiums}} {{Serie A venues}} {{Coord|44|29|32.33|N|11|18|34.80|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dall'Ara, Renato}} [[Category:Football venues in Italy]] [[Category:Serie A venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Bologna]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Italy]] [[Category:Bologna F.C. 1909]] [[Category:1934 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:1990 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1927]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Italy]] {{Italy-sports-venue-stub}}
